dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, except for the whisper of the wind. A WHITE SCREEN resolves into a wide view of a 19th centur cemetery, its dark contours softened by several inches of fresh snow. Big, wet flakes float down from a leaden sky. Wealthy MOURNERS stand under black umbrellas at an open grave as pallbearers slide a gleaming ebony coffin from a horse-drawn hearse. A legend FADES ON:

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON, 1886
dialogues.text: CAMERA DESCENDS to find a solemn, bespectacled child, EDI CUSHING, age 10, in a black coat and hat. Her delicate features are half-hidden behind a mourning veil. Frightened, the child clings to the gloved hand of her ta bearded father (CARTER CUSHING, 48). *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first time I saw a ghost, I was ten. It was my Mother's- * The coffin passes before the child's pale face.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At that age, I barely understood what had happened. She had died of Cholera- * (beat) And on account of her disease, Father * ordered that the casket remain closed... As the coffin is lowered unto the earth- *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coffin-like grandfather clock is TICKING in an enormous gas-lit bedroom. Shadows seem to swallow up the girl's * collection of dolls and books. Snowflakes drift past the tall windows, little Edith lies bed, staring at the wall. Her EYEGLASSES are on the bedsi table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--.So there was really no last glimpse. No goodbye. (pause) That is, until she came back. The clock stops ticking, the gas lamps go dark and the floorboards CREAK. There's a rustle of silk as- - a translucent tracery of cobweb ectoplasm crosses the room, its desiccated feet not touching the ground. The bed curtains move and the bedsprings sink down. Edith freezes, her eyes wide, her head turned away. She hears a low, asthmatic sigh. A shimmering hand caresses the child's hair. Finger bones are visible. In the dark, a glimpse of a tormented face..

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -.-and I heard her voice. A throatless whisper, low and grave and full of earth. Her words seared my memory as if with fire...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER'S GHOST
dialogues.text: Edith... beware of Crimson Peak. Crying out, the child sits up and looks around. Without h glasses, the world is a blur. A HAZY FIGURE is floating away. Edith puts on her glasses No one is there. The gas lamps come back on; the clock resumes its ticking.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then she was gone. (pause) It would be years before I again heard a voice like that - or saw a dead thing come to life. But see it I did... and the horror hidden in her whispered warning would change my life forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect spring day in Boston. The gorgeous blue sky is dotted with puffy white clouds... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and below it, a city is growing.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSURE
dialogues.text: 1900 A new century has arrived and the teeming streets are ali with motorcars, bicycles and horse-drawn carriages. CAMERA FOLLOWS a veiled YOUNG WOMAN as she passes workmen paving streets and erecting power poles. Steam erupts fro pile driver... smoke roils from vats of hot tar. The young woman reaches the front door of a tea room. It' EDITH, now a pale but striking 22 year-old. She still wea glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting alone among the elegant PATRONS, Edith leafs thro a thick, handwritten MANUSCRIPT, making last-minute corrections. At the next table, the dowager MRS. WALKER and her chubby daughter EUNICE are gossiping with a group of vivacious women.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: We met him at the British Museum. Last fall. He took one look at Eunice and said she was as beautiful as anything by- by-

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Burne-Something- a painter- I think- (beat) Oh, mother, he is so handsome!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: He never took his eyes off you, did he?

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: (barely able to get a word in) Well-

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: (overlapping) -Then we all went to tea. It seems he's a Baronet—

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY GIRL 1
dialogues.text: What's a Baronet?? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith closes her book and looks at Society Girl 1.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: A Baronet is a minor aristocrat. An opportunist. A man who lives off land that others work for him.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY GIRL 1
dialogues.text: Is that so, Edith?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: That is so.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY GIRL 2
dialogues.text: Well, from what I hear, this minor aristocrat is perfectly charming and is a great dancer...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: ...who's crossed the ocean with his sister. I'm sure it's because of Eunice. He's been writing us every week.

dialogues.speaker: EUNICE
dialogues.text: Mother, he's here on business!

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY GIRL 1
dialogues.text: I'm hearing wedding bells. But that wouldn't concern you, would it, Edith?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No, it wouldn't. Edith takes off her glasses and gets up to leave. Her dre and scarf are a sombre black and navy blue silk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: I think it's a shame, Edith, I really do! A man will never notice you if your nose is buried in books.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY GIRL 2
dialogues.text: Wearing black and writing all day long - our very own Jane Austen.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (walking away) Thank you, Sally. But I would prefer Mary Shelley. And, Eunice? You don't look at all like a Burne-Jones. Not languid enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous LOBBY, bustling with activity. Carrying her Manuscript, Edith approaches a reception desk where a GUA directs her to an elevator. CAMERA LINGERS on a STATUE of man, pensive and reading, surrounded by a pile of books. This is a likeness of MR. OGILVIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the same exact position as the statue, SAMUEL OGILVIE grunts with displeasure as he leafs through Edith's work. Edith discreetly uses her glasses to see what page he's o

dialogues.speaker: OGILVIE
dialogues.text: Hrumpf- Ogilvie pointedly turns his chair around and reads some more. Finally, he puts the manuscript down. He nods slowly, replacing it in the pouch.

dialogues.speaker: OGILVIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... Miss Cushing. How is your father? Now Edith knows what he thinks of her manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I take it he said no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful dining room, with damask wallpaper and art nouveau sconces. Edith sits across from her FATHER, CARTE CUSHING (almost 60 now.) His beard is streaked with gray.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: After skimming a single chapter, Father.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Ogilvie's old-fashioned. He probably looks down on ghost stories.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's not a ghost story. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: But it has a ghost in it-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Father. It's a... conduit- (off her father's look) -a pretext, to talk about spirituality. The ghost acts as a metaphor-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Ah. A metaphor. That may be too sophisticated for me, then-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Ogilvie said it needed a love story. Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Well... does it?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Need a love story?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No!- Why? Why must a woman always write about love? Stories of girls in search of the ideal husband - or the man who eludes them?? Is there nothing else? Her father stares at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I agree. Obviously he does not. At that moment, a WHISTLE from a passing train... anda train's lights move on the sheer curtains. Obeying an old habit, Cushing checks his POCKET WATCH - and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll have a word with Ogilvie- Monday at the club. She pulls the manuscript from the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You will not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Why? Why won't you let me help you?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No- * (beat) * I have to do it myself. With my words on the page! Since I'm not "beautiful" - or "graceful" - or "charming"...

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: But you are!

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: The words have to do it. All I have are * words... and they will find their way into print. You'll see. In the meantime you just have to hear me complain... He smiles and pats his daughter's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: With pleasure, always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high, wide view of a RAILYARD with steam locomotives chuffing from a roundhouse. CAMERA PANS to a five-storey brick OFFICE BUILDING. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the large, busy outer office, a scowling Edith is sitt at someone's desk, fingers pecking on a newfangled Underw typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE, a gray-haired secretary, is showing her how to use

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: See? The carriage return is almost automatic. Just push this lever here-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Automatic. Such a horrid word, isn't it? Everything is automatic now... But - (looking at the page) -it does look stronger than longhand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's a diabolical contraption, but if you're writing to publishers, you'll get their attention. And you'll save time, I warrant.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want to save time at all. What would I do with it? THOMAS SHARPE, 38, enters. He's a well-dressed, handsome Englishman and carries a WALKING STICK and a MAHOGANY BOX Edith is too engrossed in her letter to notice him.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (to Edith) Good morning, Miss. Wham! - Edith bangs over the carriage return and looks up Sharpe blushes and removes his hat.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt, but I have an appointment with Mr. Carter Everett Cushing. Esquire.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Goodness. With the great man, himself?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I'm the- Edith signals her to be quiet. She'll handle this.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You're not late, are you? He hates that.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: In fact, I'ma bit early.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh - I'm afraid he hates that, too. Sharpe leans a bit closer.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Pardon me for asking, but - is he really as terrible as they say? Edith glances at Jane and smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe turns extended. He holds the

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: A monster.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Why would a pair of charming ladies work for such a person?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: He pays me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) True enough-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Impossible. Where is this fiend? I shall make it my business to protest, to rebuke him-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: He's just behind you, sir. to find Carter Cushing approaching, hand

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Sir Thomas Sharpe. Welcome to Boston. young man's hand an extra moment- He regards Sharpe's long, wavy hair, his walking stick an velvet-collared suit.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gestures toward Edith) May I introduce Edith, my daughter- Sharpe is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: We've just met, father. (to Sharpe) It was a pleasure to make your acquaintance, Sir Thomas. I hope the great man treats you well. She smiles sweetly at Sharpe, who looks abashed but pleas  10. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM — DAY The conference room overlooks the railyard. A dozen BANKE and INVESTORS sit at Cushing's table. Amongst them, an elderly attorney - WILLIAM FERGUSON. Sharpe's mahogany box rests near a stack of topographical maps and production charts. Alongside, a small alcohol la heats a miniature, nickel-plated boiler. He shows the from hand to

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: In the last few years, we scraped together just enough capital to reopen the mines and find what we believe are very encouraging samples. men a rough hunk of iron ore. As they pass it hand...

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: "We," you say? Who might that be?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Mining engineers. Geologists. I have their statements here-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: So- you've never done any digging yourself? (beat) In that mountain of yours?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. Cushing looks at the others: "Thought so." He opens the

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: As investors in mining, you'll want more than speculation and projections. So here, gentlemen- box to reveal a SCALE MODEL of a mining drill.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -a steam drill - my own design - that matches the output of a ten-man crew. With mechanized digging, abandoned mines can be reworked and made profitable again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He connects the little boiler. With a HISS of steam, the brass levers and gears start moving; the drill spins. The men admire its ingenuity - all except Cushing.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Turn that off, please. Sudden silence as Sharpe complies.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you come to us, having failed to raise capital in London. The Boston businessmen glance at Cushing, whose cold smil reflects open skepticism.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: London, Edinburgh, Leipzig -

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Where your family name seems to have counted for very little. The door to the conference room is ajar. Edith stands the half-hidden, peeking in like a child.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm not discussing my name. This is a new century. As a railroad man, you'll need steel-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: We have no shortage of iron ore in this country. Your holdings came to you through inheritance, did they not?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: All right, yes. My great grandfather was Lord Middleton Sharpe, first Baronet of Allerdale. But the Sharpe Mines are more than a name, sir. More than nostalgia. They are my birthright.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: And now Thomas Sharpe the Baronet -— you've come to America, where you hope to raise money to honor that birthright?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: In part, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: In this country, we don't have such traditions. The men at this table - all of us - we came up through honest, hard work. Well- almost all of us - Mr. Ferguson here is an attorney, but he can't help that-— Laughter amongst the men.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But- his father shined and repaired shoes. As for me, I started out laying those very tracks - there in the yards below - decades ago. You see? And my hands- He raises two thick, calloused hands.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -reflect who I am. Just as yours do. Softest handshake I've felt in years. (beat) We bank on effort, not privilege. Sharpe surveys at the faces of the other men, now stern a uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (touching the model drill) I believe that inventions like this are equal to any man's hard work. I make no apology for my dreams... A TRAIN puffs by in the railyard. Cushing checks his pock watch.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Take your toy, young man, and dream somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Mr. Cushing, I have tried to be as frank as possible, but you've not given me a fair hearing.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: No? Well, you may attribute it toa Yank's lack of breeding. Sharpe is devastated but silent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew just how he felt, this fellow dreamer, when I saw him facing defeat. Sharpe turns and meets Edith's eyes. She darts out of sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith sits at her desk, writing in her diary. Behind her, a framed CHILD'S DRAWING of a ruddy mountain thrusting up into a blue-black sky. The schoolgirl letter beneath it reads: C-R-I-M-S-O-N P-E-A-K. The room is a bohemian hodgepodge of books, paintings, ru and tapestries.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Over the next few days, Sir Thomas Sharpe walked the muddy, torn-up streets of Boston in search of an investor. I, meanwhile, had found inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith stealthily follows Thomas Sharpe through a series o rejections: AT THE BANK, she observes through an open door. AT A GENTLEMANS' CLUB she peers through a window. AT A MEETING HALL he is, again, sent away.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I would rethink my book. I would try my hand at romance after all. For the first time the genre appealed to me. Sharpe finally reaches a deserted alley. Exhausted and furious, he throws down his papers and the mahogany box. Once he's gone, Edith steps out from hiding and looks at smashed MINIATURE and the multitude of gears spilled on t ground.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mirror in his front hall, Carter Cushing checks hi white tie and tails. As a SERVANT brings him his hat and coat, Edith enters, wearing a simple house dress.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I do wish you'd change your mind and come along. It's not just another party. Not that there's anything wrong with a simple party, mind you.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You know I can't bear such things.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: There's a performance of some kind, a woman's playing Chopin. Or is it Ravel..? I can't keep ‘em straight. (pause) And little Lord Fauntleroy will be there.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You mean Thomas Sharpe?

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: None other. I saw you spying on us, child.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I found him interesting, it's true. Like a character, in a play.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: A bad actor, you mean. Nothing to swoon about.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Nobody's swooning. But tell me: were his ideas so outrageous as to merit such a quick dismissal?

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: It wasn't his ideas, my love. I felt a lack of focus. Is he the inventor of a steam drill? Or a mine owner seeking to exploit his holdings? There's something ill-defined about him; you can't do business with men like that. The DOORBELL rings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That'll be young Dr. McMichael. He's brought his new motorcar. That's a good fellow- He's-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) I know, Father- he's got such a firm handshake... The servant opens the door and shows in DR. ALAN McMICHAE 31, a serious, bearded internist. He, too, is in formal wear. Cushing dons

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Cushing. Hello, Edith...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Good evening, Alan. My, don't we look smart.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (blushing) Not really. No more than your average penguin.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: It's Edith who should be the belle of the ball, don't you agree, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (gazing at her) Change your mind, Edith. With you, I could actually dance.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You lads will have much more fun without me. (to Dr. McMichael) Don't let him drink too much. (to her father) And no pontificating, brawling or flirting, either. No matter how fetching the ladies. his hat and coat.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I'll be a saint! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The old man chortles - Edith's the love of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith sprawls on her bed, engrossed in a thick book reple with maps of England.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was busy reading about iron mining in * the North of England. * Outside, RAINDROPS spatter the windows. Sharpe's half- assembled MINIATURE DRILL stands on the desk. Edith turns a page and stumbles upon an old engraving of mining operation in Cumberland.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I found the Sharpe mines, in a barren landscape at the base of a mountain... * Outside, a distant RUMBLE of thunder. And behind her - th miniature steam drill tumbles off the desk and crashes to the floor. * Edith leaps to her feet. The mirrored door to an ARMOIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: opens and something recedes into a darkness. Only the hem a dress is visible. Edith recognizes it.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (whisper) Mother-? She approaches the corner and descries the rippling shape a WOMAN - shadow upon shadow. A cadaverous FACE seems to emerge from the darkness, with enormous eyes, wet with tears. * As Edith suppresses a scream - a TAP on the door and a MA SERVANT leans in.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss - Edith spins around, then glances back, seeing nothing now just a dark dress hanging in the armoir. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right, miss? Whatever is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Nothing. You - you startled me, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: There's a Thomas Sharpe at the door, he's * dripping wet and most insistent on coming in.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thomas Sharpe? At this hour?? It's out of * the question, Annie. *

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: I told him, miss. He won't go away. * Edith dons a dressing gown and goes to the window overlooking the rainy courtyard. Thomas Sharpe stands at front door, holding an umbrella. He's wearing white tie a tails. She removes her glasses and opens the window.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Sharpe. Father's not home, I'm sorry to say.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Of course he's not! He's gone - maybe by gondola - to the reception at the Walker house. Which is my destination, too

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But that's in Roxbury. This is Back Bay. You're very much off course.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Not at all, my dear Miss Cushing. I've found you, haven't I? I don't think I can * brave the best of Boston society without you as my guide.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Miss Eunice Walker, I believe, will be waiting for you. With open arms. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: The devil take Miss Eunice Walker! Please, am I to make a wretch of myself? Am I to beg- Sharpe kneels among the puddles.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm lost in a strange city. A child- a mere child. And I desperately need your help.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (smiling now) Help with what?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Well, the language, for one. As you see, I don't speak a word of American. Edith laughs. She glances back into the room, where Sharp model drill lies in pieces on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mr. Sharpe. Tonight's already been somewhat... strange. For whatever reason, I'm seeing things.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Wonderful! Come with me and we'll see them together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of Boston society is seated in a ballroom where a pia recital is underway. In the audience: Eunice Walker, her mother and Society Girls 1 & 2. At the keyboard is a striking blonde WOMAN with chiseled features and an intense air of concentration. This is LUCILLE SHARPE, 40, Thomas' sister. She concludes a brilliant Chopin Polonaise and stands to acknowledge the APPLAUSE. Eunice brings her an armful of roses; they exchange warm kisses to renewed applause and approving murmurs. Taking a final bow, Lucille's expression darkens: her brother has entered the room, accompanied by a transforme Edith. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A new BUZZ from the guests as they take notice. Edith is vision of understated elegance in pale blue satin. Seeing her on Sharpe's arm, Eunice Walker and her mother are crestfallen. Cushing leaves his seat and hurries over to his daughter. he acknowledges Sharpe...

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I congratulate you, sir. Only remarkable .-.persistence could bring my daughter out of her cave.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Glad to be of service, Mr. Cushing. Like her father, she was not easily moved.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: None of us are, Mr. Sharpe. What did he promise you, Edith?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Nothing, father. I'm just more pliable than you. Dr. McMichael approaches, dazzled by her appearance.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Alan. May I introduce Sir Thomas Sharpe? (to Sharpe) This is Dr. McMichael. The man to see in Boston if you're feeling poorly.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: That's quite a glowing presentation, Edith-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: He's brilliant. If you have aches and pains- Dr. McMichael lowers his head, even more disappointed at this.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: But I've never felt better, Miss Cushing, thanks to you. (shaking the Doctor's hand) A pleasure to meet you, sir, under any circumstances. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Outside - a brief flicker of LIGHTNING... and more THUNDE rolls over the city. An exclamation from the crowd as the room GOES DARK. SERVANTS scurry to light candelabras, which give the room romantic and mysterious glow. The befuddled hostess, MRS. WALKER brings the beautiful blonde pianist over to them. But as she moves through the room, a shadow seems to follow... ---and within it Edith sees a pair of pinprick eyes glittering in a sallow face. She recoils, again recognizi the ghost of her mother. But the stout and imposing Mrs. Walker blocks her view.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: Good evening, Sir Thomas, you honor us. Welcome to our fair city.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we're late. He kisses Mrs. Walker's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: Oh, a kiss. How very rare that is today. Eunice can't wait to say hello. (turning to Edith) Edith. What a surprise. Seeing you... sparkle. As the ghostly image of her mother blurs and rises toward the ceiling, a flustered Edith tries to collect herself. Lucille is watching her closely.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our magnificent pianist is Lucille Sharpe, who's come with her brother all the way from Cumberland, in England- or is it Scotland?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Ah. That thorny question dates back to before the Norman conquest.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's in Northern England, Mrs. Walker, made famous by Mr. Wordsworth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Exactly, Miss Cushing. Although Dove Cottage is a long, long way from where we live. Mrs. Walker takes Sharpe by the arm and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WALKER
dialogues.text: Eunice is here, Mr. Sharpe, waiting in the dark with her friends. They insist on hearing your wonderful accent. (beat) Of course, we've heard English accents before, but yours is so- so- very... Thomas is quickly surrounded by a cloud of excited young women. Eunice shoulders her way to the front of the pack. Edith's eyes apparition.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Edith) All that adoration. He positively basks in it. dart over the room, ready for another

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Word travels quickly in Boston. Among the young females, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Do you not count yourself among them? Edith hears the woman's delicate sarcasm and finally turn to face her.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It is your brother, Miss Sharpe, who sought me out. Left to my own devices, I avoid parties like this and the waspish women who flourish here. A small string ORCHESTRA starts playing a stately passacaglia; floor. Thomas frees the servants clear the chairs from the dance himself from the girls and bows to Edith. Mrs. Walker and Eunice look on, losing all hope.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Miss Cushing. You came this far - will you venture a few steps further? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I'm not much of a dancer, Mr. Sharpe.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Could I be the judge of that?? He escorts her onto the dance floor...

dialogues.speaker: DANCING
dialogues.text: ...-where two concentric circles of GUESTS move rhythmica clockwise and counterclockwise. The steps are formal and controlled; each GUEST holds a LIT CANDLE. Sharpe grabs two candles — for Edith and one for himself. They join the outermost circle. All the while, Edith keeps a wary, distracted eye on the darkest corners. Sharpe is amused.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Miss Cushing. Whatever are you searching for? Here I am. Embarrassed, Edith gazes into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I - I'm sorry. I told you I was seeing things tonight. The guests keep moving while the music lasts, each one guarding his or her flame jealously. Its a game, not unli "musical chairs." Suddenly the MUSIC stops. JOYOUS CHAOS. Everybody covers own candle while trying to blow out others! The last pers holding a lit candle will win. The two circles shrink accordingly. The dancing resumes.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at all those long faces. Eunice, my father... and your sister.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Lucille? She just likes to worry. Any girl who crosses my path - she stands guard. The music stops again and the circles shrink some more. N only four couples remain- amongst them SHARPE and EDITH. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Maybe it was a mistake, letting you drag me out here. Mrs. Walker looks furious-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Just close your eyes, then.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And if I close them, what? They won't see me?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Precisely. Won't you try it? Edith closes her eyes and lets Sharpe guide her round and round... until the music stops. More candles go out. Now only ONE couple remains: Sharpe and Edith. They start dancing again, staring into each other's eyes. The music ceases for the last time and -after a collectiv gasp- the room falls silent. Two flames left. WHAT WILL

dialogues.speaker: HAPPEN
dialogues.text: Sharpe blows his own flame out and bows to Edith. She in turn blows out her candle... and the room explodes in applause!! Everybody is delighted. Everybody except MR. CUSHING. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERVANT places a breakfast tray on a table in Edith's bedroom. Edith, in a dressing gown, is scribbling away, w a growing stack of manuscript pages at her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, a new book took shape. All about a young man's quest to fulfill the legacy of a once-great family. I'd never thought much about the travails of the well-born. Fortunately, Sir Thomas delayed his departure, again and again... + eH (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith puts down her pen, opens the heavy drapes, she lets the sunlight flood her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith and Sharpe are picnicking on the banks of the Charl River. As Sharpe reads a few pages of Edith's manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: This fellow, "Cavendish" - your hero - has he no fears? No doubts?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Of course he does. He's haunted by his ancestors. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Haunted? Literally?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No ghosts this time. I've banished them from my fiction. But they have visited me, they really have... He takes a snapshot of Edith with a KODAK BROWNIE BOX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an exhibition of French Symbolist paintings, Edith and Sharpe stop to admire a strange, dreamlike work by Odilon Redon.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Why should it be so hard to believe? If one goes by experience and testimonies more people have seen Ghosts than kangaroos. And yet we firnly believe in Kangaroos. Sharpe laughs and brings up his Kodak... CLICK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the park, a BRASS BAND is playing a Sunday concert. Dozens of well-dressed Bostonians are seated on lawn chai enjoying some John Philip Sousa. Edith and Sharpe stand off to one side, in the shade of a elm tree. As he takes another SNAPSHOT: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: To my mind certain dismal places - houses, castles, battlefields - they can store and preserve the pain of their deceased inhabitants. Like a wax cylinder and its recorded voices...

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: And we'd need Mr. Edison to play them back -?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Stop laughing at me! That is the whole point some people can "play back" those images and sounds- some others don't have the sensibility- Sharpe notices a couple of familiar faces in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Oh, no - it's the Walker women. They haven't seen us- But Mrs. Walker and her daughter Eunice are waving at the

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: They have. And hope springs eternal. Come, we'll join them- Eunice can teach me how to charm-— Sharpe takes her by the arm, leading her to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: You, Miss Cushing, need no help in that department. Let us away, while there's still time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STEAM LOCOMOTIVE is trundling through the freight yard below, its bell CLANGING in the darkness. Edith is alone at Jane's desk, typing up the latest chapt of her manuscript. Ready to go home, her father emerges f his office and sits down, regarding her as she works. Whe she pauses:

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Going well, I see. Your love story. She nods, and resumes typing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH a

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Has someone swept you off your feet, by any chance? Edith stops typing and looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Let me assure you, father: Thomas Sharpe is a literary godsend. Nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, you've invited him to the house, for tea...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What of it? I owe him a debt of gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: You've made a conquest, my dear, whether you know it or not. Proceed with caution, that's all I ask. Edith has resumed her typing, a pencil clenched between h teeth. Cushing studies her, aware of her happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greenhouse is an elegant edifice of glass and steel, lush with flowers. Edith smiles as TWO SERVANTS set out a afternoon tea on a table near the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's all beautiful. Where is Mr. Sharpe?

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: I saw him in the orchid rows, ma'am, with his sister. Edith nods and moves away. She slows down as she hears VOICES.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is not what we agreed upon. It is not-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What difference does it make to you? None! It is my task- My duty- Is it so wrong for me to decide how to go about it?? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When Edith comes into view, the discussion ends, but Luci is visibly upset. She storms out.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Edith) My sister- she is yet to grow accustomed to your country, Edith. And she's tired of my frustrations, too. I daresay she has reached her limit... He sees a MANUSCRIPT in Edith's hands. His expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Don't tell me. You've finished Chapter Three?? She bursts out laughing as he playfully pulls it from her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn breaks over the quiet city. A few carriages move through deserted streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the carriages stops in front of a Gothic Revival building. The driver opens the door and a rotund, faintly raffish man gets out: MR. HOLLY. He has a large ENVELOPE in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holly is received by a STEWARD who shows him the way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swimming pool inside a domed space done up in Oriental tiles and arches. Alone in the pool, swimming laps, is Cushing. Even in lat middle age, his steady strokes are witness to enormous energy. He climbs out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Mr. Holly! I like the club first thing in the morning. I have it all to myself. A Negro SERVANT hands him a towel and robe.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: A great way to start the day, sir-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Isn't it? And perhaps a good time to end certain things, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cushing towels away the water.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I didn't expect to see you again so soon, Holly. What am I to make of it? Good news or bad?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I don't make such judgments, Mr. Cushing. I just gather the facts and leave the rest to the client. Cushing opens the envelope and scans the contents, which include letters, telegrams and yellowing civil transcript

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The English peerage and family tree was easy enough to locate - as were the property records, all the way back to the sixteen hundreds. For the banking information, I relied on a colleague in Manchester. One particular piece of paper catches Cushing's attention

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that - that document... The Civil Registry - that's the real find. CUSHING examines a document emblazoned with the CUMBERLAN SEAL - an EAGLE AND A MOUNTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: You'll have your money tomorrow, Holly. Share this with no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a dozen 29.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: CARRIAGES and a couple of MOTORCARS are parked in the courtyard of the Cushing house. Among the arriving GUESTS - Ferguson, Dr. McMichael... th Sharpe and his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a radiant their coats, with Cushing.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Edith greets the guests and a SERVANT takes Sharpe and Lucille find themselves face to face

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: May I thank you for this invitation, Mr. Cushing? It's most welcome - I know I've monopolized your daughter... and I've worried that it might not sit well with you.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: It did not. I've been most displeased. (to Lucille) Hello, Miss Sharpe. May I ask - are you the older sibling?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps you already know what your little brother is about to learn: "The truth will out."

dialogues.speaker: S LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Cushing guides Sharpe and Lucille away from the other gue and into his private library. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Now. Sir Thomas. The first time we met, at my office-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I recall it, sir. I recall it perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I imagine it wasn't hard for you to realize I didn't like you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You made that plain enough to him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Lucille- please...

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: My daughter, later on, asked me why.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Sir, I am aware that in the business world I have no advantage, no position to offer. But-—

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: But you love her, is that what you mean to say?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, it is.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Well, as I said: my daughter asked me why I didn't like you. Honestly, at the time, I had no good answer. But-— He pulls out the envelope from Mr. Holly.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, I do. Lucille opens the envelope and a single glimpse of the se is enough. Her face grows pale and rigid. She turns to Sharpe- who doesn't even look.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Does she know?

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: No. But I will tell her if that's what it takes to send you on your way.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I am sure you wouldn't believe me, but-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: You love her. I know. You're repeating yourself. He hands him a check. Sharpe and Lucille are both taken aback by the amount. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's more than generous, I know, and there's a reason. With that money you can dig iron ore to your heart's content. Build that contraption of yours. Whatever - but it will keep you far from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he gives them two STEAMSHIP TICKETS.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Majestic is sailing for Southampton on Friday. If you want to keep the money... (beat) You'd better be on it. Otherwise, that check won't clear and, one way or * another, I'll have the law on you both. Whatever continent you're on. Sharpe nods weakly.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad we understand each other. Now- (beat) As for my daughter. Without further ado- You, dear sir... (beat) --.are going to break her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight pours into the Cushing dining room, which has be decorated with cut flowers. Servants come and go with luncheon dishes. At the long table, Sharpe and his sister are the guests o honor.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) May I propose a toast of farewell? A bon voyage to Boston's questing baronet and his musical sister. A safe journey to you both. Edith stares in shock at her father - then at Sharpe. She devastated. Sharpe gets to his feet: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. When I came to America, my heart was brimming with a sense of adventure. Here the future actually means something. (beat) And although I found no financial success in Boston - He looks straight at Edith, his gaze sad and steady.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - I have found warmth and friendship among you all. And for that, I am grateful. (beat) So for now, farewell. May we meet again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chattering happily, the guests mingle in the sumptuous parlor. Sharpe approaches Edith.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: So - you are leaving us now. You might have told me.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I didn't know how. You're aware of my situation. Nothing holds me in America any longer.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Nothing. I see. He hands over her manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Here's your chapter three.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And??

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (a shrug) Your description of the garden, the maze behind the mill- it's poetic, evocative...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: And quite unnecessary. Sharpe eyes Cushing, who observes from a distance. Sharpe feels pressured.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Pray, elaborate...

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: All of it. The last ten pages. The whole chapter. I would cut it all. Wouldn't miss a thing.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But we want to know if she's going to find his letter-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Do we, really?? I don't think so- no- (beat) For the life of me, I cannot understand why you consider yourself a writer- The plot is banal... to put it plainly.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's not the tale, Mr. Sharpe but how you tell it-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Precisely my point. We've all read this tale- and many others like it. A romance gone wrong. (he shakes his head) I advise you to return to your ghost stories.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (aghast) I thank you, then, for your frankness, sir... Sharpe goes on, struggling with himself but unable to sto

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: .--but you don't have anything to say- about the natural or the supernatural, do you?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Stop- let me be- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Writing about life... the aches that you describe with such earnestness... the pain- the loss... the love. You have not lived at all... In fact, you seem to know only what other writers tell you. How can you even presume to feel-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Enough. You've made yourself more than plain.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: -how it hurts to be alone and desperate? All from your comfortable nest in- She slaps him, silencing him. The party guests gasp and stare as she flees the room. Sharpe is devastated - but Cushing smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late and dark. Edith lies in bed, wiping at her tear The floorboards creak softly. The curtains move and the bedsprings go down. Edith freezes, her eyes wide, her hea turned away. Her father's hand caresses her hair.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: I am not blind, Edith - I'm not. I know you had feelings for him. But give it time. You shouldn't be afraid of being alone- (beat) You still have me... Perhaps you and I- we could go to the West coast. A season in San Francisco. You could write and I-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Good night, Father. I love you - but good night- The old man leaves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His morning ritual: Cushing walks in, wearing his robe. An ATTENDANT appears with clean towels.

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: How's the water today, Benton??

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Just the way you like it, Mr. Cushing, sir-

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Very well, then. Be kind enough to order me some ham and eggs. I'll start with coffee, if it's hot -

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Right away, sir. As he leaves, Cushing kneels to test the water. A FIGURE comes up behind him. When Cushing turns, he smil in surprise. Then, it's too late. WHACK!!! The figure has clubbed him with a BUTCHER'S HAMM Cushing staggers, then goes down. The FIGURE stands over him, grabs his head and smashes it again and again agains the TILED CORNER of the POOL... The body rolls into the water with a soft SPLASH. The assailant withdraws. Cushing's body rocks gently back and forth, his fractured skull oozing a plume of blood into the pristine water. The attendant walks back in, sees the body and drops his tray of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith walks through the stacks of the Boston Public Libra checking some Dewey decimal numbers scrawled on the last

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: page of her chapter three. * Finally, she locates the numbered volume: a copy of Jane Eyre. Opening it up, she finds a letter from Sharpe. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Edith: By the time you read this I will be gone. So, these words are my only chance to tell you how much you mean to me. Your father asked me to break your * heart and leave you. Edith blinks and reads on as a SHADOW gathers behind her.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By this time, surely I have accomplished both. But know this: I leave only because of my present station in life. I shall change it. Even if it takes years, I shall change it - and when I can prove to your father that all I ask of him is his consent - nothing more - then, and only then will I come back for you. Forever: Thomas Sharpe. Edith turns, headed for the stairs. But a dead woman is * there. It's her mother - raising an arm, as if to block h way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, Edith sees a once-beautiful face, which is now decomposing horror. Edith drops the book and flees. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith runs down a busy dock, pushing her way through a cr of STEVEDORES and waving FAMILIES. But it's too late. By the time she arrives at the gangpla the Majestic has set sail. She stands there, panting, defeated, watching the UNION J on its stern receding. But little by little she becomes aware of another presenc standing close by. It's Sharpe. Disturbed, flustered, Edith backs away. He follows closel

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: It seems I missed my ship. On purpose, Edith. My sister - she's on board - but I couldn't go - not yet.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: When, then? When do you leave? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I don't know - I truly don't-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean? If you don't know, who does?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: You, Edith. Only you know. He pulls her close and kisses her. Edith is thrilled. She pulls away...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And what about my book? Is it so awful?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I loved every word. You must finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAXI is parked in front of the Cushing home, engine idling. A chauffeured black MOTOR CAR pulls up behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith and Sharpe are in the taxi, locked in a passionate embrace. A sudden KNOCK on the window... Ferguson, the LAWYER- opens the door. Edith takes one look at him and knows something terrible happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CORONER leads Edith, Sharpe and Ferguson down a hospita corridor. Dr. McMichael appears behind them, hurrying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (looking stricken) Edith. I'm so sorry - it's incomprehensible - I can't believe it, how could such a thing happen-? He was a dear friend, you know that- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He falters. Edith is in shock, holding back her tears. Th coroner opens the door to the morgue. Before she can ente DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) Edith. Wait. (to the coroner) I'll give you a positive identification. No need for Miss Cushing to see him. I was his physician.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: And I am his lawyer, Dr. McMichael. I am sorry- it's a legal formality. Obligatory, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: (regards Edith closely) You must concentrate on the features that remain intact, Miss. Don't fix upon broken things, things out of place-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have gathered around a draped cadaver on a steel tab The coroner pulls back the sheet, hiding the corpse from CAMERA, but revealing it to Edith. She fights back her tears as Sharpe comes alongside, steadying her. The coroner addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: As the sole surviving relative, you could request an autopsy, but in this case I don't think it's necessary. An accident - the floor was wet -

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: Ah. Of course. He slipped. Dr. McMichael gazes intently at the corpse, frowning at w he sees.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (to the coroner) May I, sir? As he inspects the dead man's skull,

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Get away from him- This is my father- my- father- my father. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He - he- is turning sixty next week - and he is- he is afraid of it showing- (breaks) Afraid of looking his age, you see? She struggles to go on.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's why he- he dresses so well- That's why he swims every day- that's why- He loves taking long walks with me- He loves it- He loves me- (beat) And now I am alone. And as she says this, she finally crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Edith is in black and surrounded by mourners the Cushing burial plot. A fresh grave lies open next to mother's granite tombstone. As the REVEREND reads a passage from the Bible (MOS), Edi leans on Sharpe's arm. A large DIAMOND RING sparkles on h finger. A bereft-looking Dr. McMichael is standing in the crowd, staring fixedly at Sharpe. It's a duel- but then, with a gentlemanly tip of Dr. McMichael's hat, it's over. Before the diggers close up the grave, Edith steps forwar and drops Cushing's pocket watch onto the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Within a few short weeks, the very same guests who mourned my father's passing attended my wedding at Trinity Church...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark shape of the S.S. Providence ploughs through the moonlit waves of the North Atlantic. CAMERA MOVES IN to o of the portholes on the "A" deck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--.and then, setting sail with Thomas I felt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first-class stateroom is filled with FLOWERS.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-.that by his side I could face any horror in the world. And I would - in time - face all of them. Edith emerges from the bathroom, her body backlit through sheer negligée. As she slips into bed, Sharpe places a wooden case by her side.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What pray tell is that?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: A surprise. Open it -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What - ? Sharpe proceeds to unlock the case.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I wracked my brains for a suitable wedding present. As usual, Lucille came to the rescue. Her idea - (he gestures to the case) - I daresay, will prove useful. It's a TYPEWRITER.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (bursts out laughing) Oh, how perfect! (kissing him) Thank you, Thomas, I love it! Shall I try it out? Right now -?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: It can wait until morning, I think. You'll have more to write about. He kisses her. As their embrace becomes passionate, he li off the nightgown and they begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING MEN are carting off the contents of Cushing's home and loading a horse-drawn dray outside. Dr. McMichael is seated at Cushing's desk, transferring t contents of the drawers into a carton. One packet of papers attracts his attention. The TOP of a page pokes out of an envelope: It is emblazoned with the Cumberland eagle and a mountain. This is the file from Holly, the private detective. As the young Doctor unfolds it, he finds that the rest of the page has been torn off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Rochet-Schneider HORSELESS CARRIAGE putters over the barren, snow-covered hills of rural Cumberland. No one el is on the road; a few woolly sheep browse the icy slopes. Sharpe is at the wheel, with Edith sitting beside him, wrapped in furs and a lap blanket. At a lonely crossroads, they make a turn, following a lin of power poles. A weathered signpost reads: SHARPETON. 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpeton is nothing but a cluster of abandoned stone cottages.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Once the mine closed, everyone left, except us. The family motto is "Semper Pertinax"-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: "Always Stubborn..?"

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: To a fault. Edith can see a grand house brooding up in the hills, its many chimneys silhouetted against the gray sky. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A FLOCK OF SHEEP crosses in front of the car, followed by sheepdog. Then, an arthritic SHEPHERD in tattered clothin runs up, saluting Sharpe with his crook.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Finlay. How have you been keeping? * Finlay's leathery, whiskered face is earnest and attentiv but his blue eyes are cloudy with cataracts.

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Never better, Sir Thomas. I knew it was you a mile off.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (as if talking to a child) Finlay, this is my wife, Edith. We were * married in Boston, Massachusetts - that's on the other side of the Atlantic Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: I know, I know, milord. You are married. (to Edith) Welcome back, Lady Sharpe! Mein Name ist William, wie sind Sie heute? (he nods, satisfied) There, I learned it! He hurries into one of the stone hovels near the road.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What on earth? Was he speaking German?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Of a kind. I'm sorry. (embarrassed) He's been here forever - he worked for my parents. The soul of generosity. We help him when we can. Finlay emerges with a beautifully carved WOODEN LAMB. He hands it to Edith.

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Here, this is for you, mum. Another one.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (uneasy) Why, thank you, Finlay! Very fine work, * as always. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But - it's beautiful! Did you make it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: (nodding) That's little Scrub. She answers to Scrub, she's the baby of the family. Put her with the rest of the flock, they'll treat her right. He touches his cap and Sharpe drives on. As Finlay recede from view:

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Was he always like that?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: More or less. The whiskey didn't help.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHARPE MANSION
dialogues.text: The car proceeds under an arch with wrought-iron letters: CLOUD TOP. As they motor up a long, steep driveway, Edith leans forward, peering through the windshield at the imposing house.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But it's enormous!

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: It does swallow one up. But we love it anyway - and you will, too, you'll see. A cute little DOG frisks around the car as they stop at t front steps. Edith gets out and picks up the dog.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And who is this? You never told me about him! (laughing) Or is he a she? Sharpe's chuckle is awkward, almost confused. SOMETHING's WRONG: he hadn't expected this.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I - I'll just let you guess -! He TOOTS the car horn and glances at the house, but there no other sign of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe unlocks the massive, oaken front door and Edith pe uncertainly into the foyer. She shrieks as Sharpe playful grabs her around the waist and lifts her through the port The dog barks in excitement as he carries her inside. Setting her down...

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Welcome home, my Lady!! The gloomy FOYER is paneled in dark wood. Just beyond it, staircase climbs through three open floors and jutting balconies. At its center: a caged elevator. Edith wanders uncertainly, like Jonah inside the whale.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Lucille? He tries a wall switch: no lights.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lucille? He exits the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The electric service is new - wait here, I'll only be a moment. Edith becomes aware that the dog has grown quiet; its tai curls between its legs. Shivering, Edith pulls her coat tight around her. Behind her, the door blows shut with a soft BOOM. Even darker no Somewhere, a FLY is buzzing. A motionless, silhouetted WOMAN in black is in an adjoini passageway. She stands straight, with preternatural digni

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lucille? The woman's pince-nez glasses gleam; a diamond RING flash on her finger. The dog GROWLS. Just then, the wall sconces blaze up in a warm and cheerf light. Sharpe reappears, wiping his hands on a rag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I have no idea what I'm doing with fuses and the like. Electricity is the work of the devil - (beat) We keep a box of candles in every room and now you know why - Edith seizes his arm, spinning him around to face the wom gone now.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I saw somebody -

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Somebody?? Don't be silly. We're alone here - there's not a living soul for miles. Unless you count Finlay and his flock.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Wh- where's your sister? Sharpe presses a brass CALL BUTTON. Somewhere below, machinery WHIRS. CABLES move.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: She'll be upstairs. Come - here's the lift. The CAGED LIFT rises into view.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It goes to all the floors and down two levels to the old mine offices. (beat) Don't ever go below this floor, all right? No place for you.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: At the far end of a cavernous grand stairwell, Sharpe and Edith exit the elevator and proceed down the murky hall.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Lucille?  46.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Heavy furniture and floral wallpaper. A fireplace in the corner. Sharpe deposits the cases on the four-poster bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'll get a fire going. Once it's lit, this room stays toasty warm - Edith places Finlay's hand-carved lamb on a shelf, then * draws back a curtain, revealing barren, dark hills * overlooking a valley hundreds of feet below. A few * snowflakes are drifting down. *

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lucille may be in the coal shed. Or the * garage. I'll just go see. * He leaves. Pleased with the room, Edith removes her hat a gloves, then goes to the mirror, where she takes a moment gaze at her reflection. With a coquettish smile, she takes off her eyeglasses.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lady Sharpe, do you take milk or lemon? Won't you try a nice, warm scone? She becomes aware of a few drowsy HOUSEFLIES vibrating - agonizing - on the windowsill. She opens the window and shoos them outside, catching sig of Sharpe headed for a garage at the side of the house. * With a grin, she opens her mouth to call out to him. But-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Edith. Get out... * Edith whirls around - she's alone.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Coming out into the hall without her glasses, Edith squints... A faint CLUNK and the WHINE of machinery. Down the hall, elevator cables are moving. A moment later, the cab comes up; a WOMAN is on board. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (relieved) Lucille! We've been- The elevator door opens revealing... * .-.a walking horror with wild grey hair tumbled over nake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shrunken breasts. The woman's tongue, lips and throat are stained black; her eyes are pits of darkness.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Leave us- Now! Edith covers her face as the skeletal figure reaches for her. RIP - !! A three-inch tear appears on Edith's blouse Stifling a cry, Edith runs in the other direction, collid with Sharpe, who's coming up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Who was that -? Oh, my God, Thomas - Who, * in God's name is that woman                        ! Who is in this house?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Shhh, Edith- Lucille's nowhere to be -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Not Lucille! Someone else, just now! And - (pointing) - she came up on that - you saw it coming up, the elevator...! Sharpe puts his hands on her shoulders and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Edith, please- calm down- I have no idea what-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Look - it tore my blouse, I felt it!

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: What have you done? Good lord. Here, let me show you something. Come - He leads her into the elevator cab. Points at a mirror on the back wall inside the cab.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A rusty silver mirror - rotting away, that's all - and you, my darling, without your glasses! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith looks at her reflection.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No - that's not it. Thomas, I - I'm scared-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Shh- Shh- Come.
On board the lift, Sharpe closes the glass doors and move the brass lever downward. As they slowly descend:

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Now. This thing has a mind of its own. In fact, I prefer the stairs. In our mother's day, it was operated by half a dozen servants in the basement, hauling on ropes. Lucille had it motorized and it's been quite a comedy ever since. Through the glass panels, Edith can see the foyer coming under her feet.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I want to leave, please. This - this is one of those places, I can feel it- a container, full of souls in pain, hateful creatures...

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Ah- your love affair with ghosts. Here, in the very house where I grew up! I should be offended-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He centers the lever and the elevator gently stops. He op the door, revealing the dark shape of another WOMAN. Edith leaps back - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Lucille Sharpe, in gloves and heavy woolens, musteri a chilly smile.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: There you are! The two weary travelers. So, Edith, welcome to Cloud Top. Hullo, Thomas - why don't you have a fire going!? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: We've only just arrived, my dear. Where have you been! Lucille throws off her cape and shakes off some snowflake

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: In Strathney. Your machine parts are here from Birmingham. Four crates - Fraser needs you to arrange for delivery. I stopped at the Post Office, too. (back to Edith) You have a letter from Boston. Go on, open it. (inspects the envelope) It's from a Mr. Ferguson. Your solicitor. I mean, lawyer, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Not now, Lucille, I beg you. Give us a moment- Edith's in a state. As Lucille hangs up her winter clothing: Edith covers

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Why is that, Edith? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: She saw something - a shadow, a reflection -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Edith) And it tore your dress?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: As you see. It's a presence, am I right, darling? Ghosts, shades or whatnot, whose souls are imprinted within the walls. Stored there, if I understand correctly. her face with her hand, feeling a fool.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (bracing up) Piffle. I've gone mad. It never happened.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You're overtired - after such a long journey..?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Not a bit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You're missing your father, then. My condolences on his passing - so tragic.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I need a proper welcome, that's all! Here, Lucille - give me a kiss. She embraces her sister-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (kissing Lucille) From this day forward, this house will contain nothing but warmth, friendship and love. I hereby banish all shades of melancholy. Away, you ghosts. Begone, dull care Over Edith's shoulder, Sharpe locks eyes with Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Hear, hear. And congratulations, Edith. What a beautiful bride you are. PRELAP: the notes of a Chopin nocturne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a raised bay in the Sharpe library, Lucille is seated a GRAND PIANO, playing with her usual concentration. Sipping a BRANDY, Edith strolls around the magnificent double-height room, which is crowded with books and glass cabinets. Oil portraits stare down from the walls; stuffe animals mingle with other souvenirs of a well-traveled family. A stained-glass window bears a family coat-of-arms: "Semp Pertinax."

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I do... it's almost a church...

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I spent my childhood in here. The dog trots into the room, going directly to Edith. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HHH HH OF

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lucille, what is the dog's name? I seem to have a new and faithful companion- Lucille's eyes are closed as she plays the Chopin.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: The dog... has no name. It's a stray, we have no plans to keep it. The dog leads Edith to a stack of GERMAN BOOKS on the flo She picks one up and looks at the flyleaf.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And these books... are in German-? Lucille stops her piano playing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Those books belonged to a house guest. Do you read German, Edith?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: A few words, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Sharpe) I've been wanting to donate them to the local library, haven't I, Thomas-? No reason to keep them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bookplate reads: Von der Sammlung von Eleanora Schott Below, the woman's signature, in an elegant, Continental hand. And the year, 1897.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Edith sniffs the book, noting the scent of perfume.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And the piano? Lucille, is this where you learned to play?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Not really. I was sent away. We both were, in actual fact. Separated. Edith is puzzled; she looks at her husband. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But why? Such a cruel thing - whose idea was that?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: The estate's executors in Carlisle. After mother's death. He guides her to an OIL PAINTING of their mother - LADY SHARPE - over the fireplace. It's a high-quality portrait an imposing woman in pearls, silk, an ivory cane and pinc nez glasses.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see? A famous beauty in her day. SILENCE as Edith frowns, remembering the apparition she s in the foyer. This is the same woman. A soft MOAN fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (looking around) What in God's name...?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Ah, that. Some of the mine tunnels run directly beneath the house. When the wind picks up, the chimneys form a vacuum - ghastly, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Can something be done about it? I've had more than enough scares already, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: It's no use. I can remember crying every time I heard it, when I was in this room as a child.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: It never bothered me. You know, I'm the practical one, like Mother. Edith looks back at the portrait.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lucille: you look so like her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (bursts out laughing) What an imagination you have, Edith! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thomas, isn't that funny? I look like her...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: May I ask, how did she die?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: A seizure, here at home.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And your father? Was he already dead?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Yes, father died when we were very small.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: How sad, for both of you! Just think how * happy he'd be to see you now, all grown * up with a blushing bride at your side. * She kisses him, then realizes that Lucille has left the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe pokes up the fire, then gets into bed, where Edith propped up on pillows, reading FERGUSON'S LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: What does he say?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Probate is almost complete. The house and its contents are sold. The bank papers will be sent for my signature. (kisses him) I've been practicing my new signature. "Edith Sharpe." Is it a good author's name, Thomas? Or should I publish under Cushing, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I think you'd better finish the book. Then you can decide what your admirers should call you. More kisses; soon they are making love on the canopied be  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille lies awake in her bed in a room down the hall, listening to the MOANS of the lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dull, gray day. Behind the house, a prominent, rocky HI denuded of trees, juts skyward. *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Dear Mr. Ferguson: thank you for your * recent letter. Upon receipt of the * documents, I will execute the signature * copies and send them back to your * office." *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her nightgown, Edith's at the desk, writing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "At which point all the stock * certificates, bonds and liquid assets * should be transferred to the account of Lady Edith Sharpe at the Royal Bank of Carlisle." Still in bed, Sharpe stirs, sits up and looks at Edith. W his rumpled hair and sleepy grin, he looks like an impish boy.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Edith: it's far too early for any of your pen pushing. You must at least wait.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Wait for what, my love? Sharpe draws back the down quilt, inviting her to return bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: For further inspiration. Come. Edith lays down her pen and goes to him.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse-drawn FARM WAGONS and local PEDESTRIANS crowd the t center on a cold, wet afternoon. Sharpe steers his car to a stop outside a FREIGHT OFFICE the high street. As a SHIPPING AGENT appears to usher him inside, Edith an Lucille exit the car. Lucille disappears into an adjacent DRY GOODS STORE. Edith heads for the POST OFFICE across t street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the counter, the POSTAL CLERK affixes a stamp onto Edith's reply to Ferguson. As Edith counts out some coins the clerk notes her name on the return address.

dialogues.speaker: POSTAL CLERK
dialogues.text: You're Lady Sharpe, then? Forgive me, mum, but there's a letter come in for you just this morning. He disappears for a moment, then returns with an envelope Handing it to her: POSTAL CLERK (CONT’D) All the way from Germany. Edith frowns, looking at the address, written in an elega cursive hand: Lady E. Sharpe Poste Restante, Strathney Cumberland, United Kingdom POSTAL CLERK (CONT’D) Is there anything the matter, mum? Edith is examining the postmark: Leipzig.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No, nothing at all. Thank you so much. She tucks the letter into her handbag, then sees a happy Sharpe waving to her from the barn-like freight depot acr the street. a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HHH FH HH HH HK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. DEPOT — DAY At a loading dock, Sharpe proudly shows Edith the content of several OPEN CRATES. Packed in sisal, gleaming GEARS, AXLES and HOSES.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thomas! Is that the Ore drill - ?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: It will be, once I put it together. I'm having the bit fabricated separately, in Glasgow. The shipping agent approaches with a BILL.

dialogues.speaker: SHIPPING AGENT
dialogues.text: If you'll just sign here, Sir Thomas. As Sharpe signs the paper: SHIPPING AGENT (CONT’D) Will you be wanting it this afternoon, then?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yes, please. And think lucky thoughts, Mr. Fraser - the Sharpe Mines might re- open if this thing cooperates. The man nods and withdraws. Sharpe shows the bill to Edit

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never had enough money to get this far. Now, thanks to a certain gentleman in Boston -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Boston -?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: - who shall remain anonymous -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No! You found an investor? Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: In good time, my darling, all will be revealed. Suffice to say that meeting you made all the difference. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL, (V.O.)
