dialogues.text: (prelap) As the body dies- as its organs shut down... a weight change occurs. It loses exactly 21 grams.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: People of faith claim this is the weight of the soul leaving the body, but I urge you, as men of science, to dismiss such a notion. The Doctor lectures in an operating theatre, where a body lies before him, flayed open. In the gallery, dozens of students take notes and make sketches.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Physical humours evaporate, secretions leave the body through open pores- that and the air, leaving the lungs... This is what you must look for, gentleman. Not faith, not magic, just science. CAMERA singles out a man seated among the students: the lawyer, Mr. Ferguson. As Dr. McMichael sees him: DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) We must question every detail before us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea is being served to Dr. McMichael and Ferguson.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: It all seems to have ended well enough. Edith seems to have found happiness, don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I haven't had a word.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: Damn, that's a shame. (pause) Well, I have. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing personal, of course. Per her instructions, I'm liquidating all the family assets.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Are you really?

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: Quite unusual. She may be investing every penny. Those iron mines of his- (speaking quietly) If I might confide-? Dr. McMichael puts down his tea, leaning close. FERGUSON (CONT’D) Before Cushing died, he hired a New York man, a Mr. Holly- very hard to track down. He digs up unsavory facts, haunts places not suitable for a gentleman. The very fact that Holly was involved gives me pause.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I follow-

dialogues.speaker: FERGUSON
dialogues.text: Cushing was no fool. And he liked you, Doctor- he did. He always mentioned you as someone worthy of his trust- and his daughter. Ferguson writes something on the back of a card. FERGUSON (CONT’D (CONT’D) Now, it's clear that Cushing had his doubts about Sharpe. I myself would love to visit Edith- wish her the best. Seeing as I have her address... He passes the Doctor the card. FERGUSON (CONT’D) But I am old and tired. A trip like that requires some stamina... (beat) If you are the man Cushing believed you to be... you should be the one making that house call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steady SNOWFALL is transforming the vast landscape. A couple inches have already covered the house and its many gables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam billows in the vast tile bathroom as Edith waits fo the tub to fill with hot water. She opens the envelope fr Leipzig and finds a letter written in German.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (reading) "Mein liebe Eleanor..." Puzzled, she sets it aside, drops her robe and gets into bath. Gazing at the wedding ring on her finger, she grows dreamy, until... -..-she sees a FLY crawling on the window pane. A sudden RASP at the door makes her jump - but it's only dog, scratching. It enters and sits... then turns its hea as the fly zooms past. SNAP! The little dog's jaws click shut on the insect. GUL down it goes. The dog's pink tongue appears, licking its chops. Edith laughs. INT. KITCHEN —- DAY In the cavernous, skylighted kitchen, Lucille is at the stove, which is as large as a hay wagon. Edith enters, the dog in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Good morning, Lucille!

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Good morning. I've made porridge, if you'll eat it.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But that's awful, Lucille - ! I mean, you making my breakfast! Here, let me do something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She puts down the dog and heads for the stove.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: No. And I prefer the dog be kept out of the kitchen. * Edith scoots the dog into the hall, closes the door and smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: There. Gone. Where is Thomas? * Lucille's eyes look tired and distant.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: In the garage, assembling that thing of * his. *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lucille, don't tell me you're a skeptic.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: It's a pipe dream, an utter waste of money. I long ago accustomed myself to the reality of our situation - Thomas never has. Do you prefer coffee or tea? +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Lucille, I'll not have you cook my meals * and do for me in any other way. Believe it or not, I know my way around a kitchen. Pause. Then, Lucille nods in understanding, brushing back lock of hair.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I'm a sour old thing in the morning. Let me warn you, however: there's more than enough work here for everyone- no servants- we can't afford them.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Soon, we will. Father's assets are being * transferred here. With a house this grand, that money will be put to good, practical use- I think he'd be pleased. Edith checks the fire under one of the cast-iron platters She picks up the coal scuttle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So. Where's the coal kept? No answer from Lucille, whose face has again grown stony.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Edith. Did you tell my brother about this bank transfer?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (nodding) It was in Mr. Ferguson's letter... Thomas hasn't mentioned it? *

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (dry) No. Not a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith comes down a gloomy, frigid corridor behind the kitchen. A dark SHAPE darts out at her feet: the dog agai It follows Edith to a small door, the entrance to the coa shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GARAGE —- SAME In the cavernous garage, Thomas is crouched beside a stea boiler, fitting a hose to a pressure gauge. The senile shepherd Finlay is there, too, sitting among the crates, singing to himself as he polishes a flywheel. + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille enters, wrapped up in a shawl. Sharpe looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You and I must talk. We keep nothing from each other, is that not so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal is piled up against the rough wooden walls of the se detached storage shed. Frost covers the single small wind (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith shivers; she can see her breath. There are COBWEBS everywhere, all of them dotted with dea flies. With a shovel, Edith fills the coal scuttle... the turns to go. No dog now.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Where are you..? Come, doggie... A SIGH shakes the spider webs; dead flies drop to the flo In a matter of seconds, it grows dark. Edith looks out th window - at a night sky with scudding moonlit clouds..! Disbelieving, Edith turns around; a cloud of white VAPOR hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Still here...!? Edith backpedals as another sinuous strand of vapor gathe before her.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stupid creature... Edith grabs a handful of COAL DUST and flings it. The bla particles settle on a YOUNG WOMAN'S FACE hovering in mida The mouth is moving even as the glittering eyelids stay shut.

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: ..-leave ussss- ! A CLANG as Edith drops the coal scuttle and trips on a board. She falls heavily - and looks up as... --.-coal dust swirls and rains down upon her. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and Lucille's conversation is interrupted by BARKI The dog charges into the garage, followed by Edith, whose hands and dress are filthy black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurtles past brother and sister to the Rochet-Schneid motorcar. Sharpe manages to stop her, but she tears free, intent on getting behind the wheel. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Edith -! Edith, what is it..!? He forcibly turns her around; her eyes finally focus on h Then she looks around the garage, becoming aware of where she is.

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: (doffing his cap) Guten tag, guten tag, alles... INT. BEDROOM —- DAY Edith has taken refuge on the bed, hiding like a child un the quilt. Sharpe is seated alongside her, holding her ha

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Your hand's like ice! Are you running a fever -? Look at me... (seeing her face) What in God's name- ? She sits up and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thomas: I saw a face - a woman, she was alive, not a shadow, not trick of the light -

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Whose face? (concerned) Edith - shh, I'm here. Did you recognize her? Was it someone you know?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No, no - it was- a different woman this time. Young. Blind. In moonlight!- A TAP at the door and Lucille enters, carrying a breakfas tray. Edith clings to Sharpe, trying to regain control of herself.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (aghast) Blind, you say?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (nodding) I know this much... Lucille sets the tray down on the bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shuddering) It wants me out of here. Hands shaking, Edith takes a sip of tea.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Nonsense, my dear. Your arrival has brought us hope. *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What about me? If I can't tell what's * real, how can I stay here? * She puts on a painful smile; her hands are shaking. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send the hysteric to Vienna. She's ready for Dr. Freud.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Never, ever. Cloud Top is your home now. * And as dull as it sounds to the Austrian * alienists, ours is a material world. That * much is indisputable. From the hallway downstairs, there's a BOOMING KNOCK on t front door. A TEAMSTER calls out:

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse-drawn DELIVERY VAN has pulled up out front. Two WORKMEN stomp through the snow, unloading a shipment of CRATES and TRUNKS. The elderly teamster doffs his cap when he spots Sharpe throwing open the upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: "Morning, Sir Thomas! Sorry we're late - the road's that bad, over a foot here and there! Finlay walks up with his sheepdog. *

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: With more snow coming! (to the teamster) Hello, Malcolm! Anything for me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: Could be, Finlay, could be. We'll take a look. As Sharpe and the men converse (MOS):

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They said the arrival of my things from home - my "goods and chattels" Thomas called them - would calm me down. I didn't believe them, but I decided I must try. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped in a heavy coat, Edith stands on the front porch surrounded by open crates, sorting through her things as workmen carry lamps and vases inside. The teamster pauses to give Finlay a bottle of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: Make it last, now. Might not see you for weeks, if the road's closed...

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: You're a godsend, Malcolm... In a box full of books, Edith comes upon her framed childhood drawing of Crimson Peak. CRACK!!! The glass in the frame SHATTERS. Edith gasps.. The teamster looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: That's a shame, mum. There's a shop in Strathney can order you a new glass - (noticing the caption) "Crimson Peak"?!

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (recovering) As a child, I - I had an active imagination. This mountain had to be red, red, red- Fascinated, Finlay seizes Edith by the arm and eagerly pu her along the verandah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Crimson Peak? Come see! * CAMERA DOLLIES with them to reveal the hill behind the * house, which is now snow-covered and glowing like an imme ruby in the morning sun. *

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Finlay. * (explaining to Edith) Color crimson on account of the ore leaching up from below. In summertime, it's more of an orange-like, but by Winter the snow turns blood red. (beat) Crimson Peak all the same. That's what us locals call it- +e * HF Sharpe comes up, holding a couple of Edith's books.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Look, darling, we have the very same edition of The Tales of Hoffmann - * He falls silent when he sees the expression on her face.

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTER
dialogues.text: Just a bit of broken glass, sir. He indicates Edith's drawing behind the cracked glass. TEAMSTER (CONT’D) Quite a coincidence, ain't it? They all compare Edith's artwork to the real thing: an uncanny match. Edith's mind is racing... back to memories her mother's warning. TEAMSTER (CONT’D) Was Lady Sharpe here as a child, sir? Is that it? Sharpe is looking with concern at Edith.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's a coincidence - nothing more -—

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: A blessing, then. A blessing. Not a coincidence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He embraces her. But his face is troubled. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crimson Peak is a dull, ruddy shape half hidden behind a new, heavy SNOWFALL. * CAMERA BOOMS DOWN to find Sharpe helping Lucille into the motorcar in front of the house. Edith is there to see the off. *

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (worried, to Edith) * Will you not come with us? Promise me you * won't summon forth new beings from the * netherworld- *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Shh. Stop. I'm going to work like a * scholar. It's high time I got back to the * book. *

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Then, write, do you hear me?? You have a * whole day to yourself! Make the most of it! As they drive off, Edith waves from the bottom of the sno covered front steps. She picks up the little dog and regards the front door, o and gaping as if ready to gobble her up. A gust of wind and the house moans. Edith shivers, then g inside and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith stands in the middle of the coal shed, studying the gloomy corners. Silence. She loads the coal scuttle, takes a defiant last look around, then leaves. Outside, the snow is piling up. The sound of TYPING. *

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "My... dear... Eleanor..." *  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coal fire is glowing. The faithful dog lies at Edith' feet as she types, translating the letter from Leipzig wi the aid of a GERMAN DICTIONARY.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ",.-Why, dear cousin, will you not answer my letters? Your little Lotte must be walking and talking by now... and still, no word of any kind. What are your English relatives doing to you?" Edith lifts her eyes. The oil portrait of the late Lady Sharpe gazes down on her.

dialogues.speaker: AMONG THE BOOKS
dialogues.text: Edith sits atop a rolling ladder, just below the portrait She moistens a handkerchief and rubs it on the canvas - - exposing, on the woman's finger, a diamond RING. She compares it to the ring she's wearing: the same. The dog's BARK reaches her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith walks through the foyer, glancing up... More barkin from upstairs. She finds herself at the lift. On impulse, she gets in and moves the brass handle to "up CLUNK - the unseen electric motor whines and the cab rais her out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the doorway of a wood-paneled STUDY, Edith surveys a workbench strewn with metal parts and blueprints - all relating to Sharpe's miniature steam drill. Edith smiles at the chaos.  69.

dialogues.speaker: A BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Edith enters Lucille's austere, sparsely-furnished bedroo A framed PHOTO of brother and sister - younger, posing ar in arm on Brighton Pier - stands on the bedside table. At the desk, she inspects a pile of ACCOUNT BOOKS, LEGAL PAPERS and a KEY RING. Some of the documents are in Germa including a letter from a bank in Leipzig. Edith comes upon an envelope with her name on it: "Edith Cushing, Boston 1900." In the envelope: SNAPSHOTS of herself back in Boston - th Kodak pictures taken by Sharpe.

dialogues.speaker: NURSERY
dialogues.text: Using Lucille's key ring, Edith unlocks a dusty room that once served as a nursery. The wallpaper features a parade merry animals. A CRADLE and TOY CHEST occupy the corner n the window. On a shelf, near a dented silver rattle and christening c she finds a BLACK RUBBER BALL.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: In the corridor, Edith hears the dog WHINING on the other side of a heavy pair of double doors. She tries the brass knobs: locked. Using another of Lucille's keys, she opens the doors onto long-forgotten passageway. PASSAGEWAY — CONTINUOUS A few SNOWFLAKES drift in from a half-open skylight. No s of the animal. As Edith latches the skylight shut, a sudden YELP... and dog is sitting at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: There you are! All right, little girl: fetch! Edith throws the rubber ball. With a BARK, the dog takes after it, disappearing into the gloom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, silly. Come on... THUMP... the ball comes bouncing back. Edith moves deeper into the frigid passageway, moving in out of shafts of light from other skylights.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, girl. Here..? She passes a stack of BRICKS, large GLASS BOTTLES filled with roofing nails, an old wicker WHEELCHAIR... and final reaches a rusty iron door only three feet high. Hearing SCRATCHING on the other side, she kneels down and tries the handle: it won't move.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did you get in there?! The SCRATCHING becomes intense, frenzied. Edith looks dow and realizes the dog is sitting alongside her - !! Flesh crawling, she gathers up the dog and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching the double doors, she glances back. Something small and skeletal is coming, scuttling over th floor, in and out of the light. It's a bony HAND! The jar of nails EXPLODES! The pile of bricks tumbles over... Edith slams the doors and throws the lock. She backs away but, like a spider, the fingers wriggle out from under th door..!

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR DOWN
dialogues.text: Edith charges into the lift and yanks the lever - and nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Down, dammit! Down!! Finally, the cab jerks, sways, and starts moving - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: - but the hand - covered in rotten flesh - is pressed against the outside of the glass, riding along! The dog thrashes in her arms, strangling in her grip. The ground floor is in sight! But the cab drops right pas itl!

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! Desperate, Edith pulls on the control handle - to no avai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A filthy BASEMENT comes into view... shelving, canned goo an ancient washer and mangle. And the elevator keeps going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-passing dark, abandoned tunnels once active with iron miners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, a gentle BUMP as the elevator stops. The HAND dr off the glass and withdraws. Edith puts down the dog and tries the lever, but the elevator won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith's groping fingers encounter a light switch. She twi the knob and a few brownish bulbs come on. Inky tunnels are everywhere, like an enlarged termite nes No movement, no sound except for the distant DRIP of wate Edith starts down steep, rickety steps, which creak in protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog trots ahead. On the rough-hewn walls hang mining tools, chains and lanterns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith moves carefully, keeping an eye out for the terribl hand - or anything else.

dialogues.speaker: ALCOVE
dialogues.text: In an alcove, she discovers a pile of women's shoes. The sniffs at them, unleashing a stampede of COCKROACHES. Edith lifts the lid of a STEAMER TRUNK and finds... ...a STRAW HAT. A WHITE CANE. A woman's SPECTACLES with BLACK LENSES. And an adorable flock of Finlay's HAND-CARV SHEEP. She examines a lace HANDKERCHIEF with an embroider monogram: ES. She smells it - recognizing the perfume. Below it, she finds three ALBUMS of Kodak snapshots. The handwritten labels on each album: "Pamela Upton - London - 1887" "Margaret McDermott - Edinburgh - 1893" "Eleanora Schott - Leipzig - 1896" She remembers that day at her father's office-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cushing peers at Sharpe at the conference table:

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: So you come to us, having failed to raise capital in London.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: London, Edinburgh, Leipzig -

dialogues.speaker: CUSHING
dialogues.text: Where your family name seems to have counted for very little.

dialogues.speaker: ALCOVE
dialogues.text: Edith opens the albums. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They all feature Thomas and several beautiful, well-dress YOUNG WOMEN. They are young and healthy, in carriages or formal wear. The youngest of them is blind and carries a white cane. The German woman is holding the cute little dog that has befriended Edith.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh, my God- A thin, malevolent WHISPER from the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Edith! Verstorben! Verstorben!! Edith snatches up an IRON BAR and strides out into the em tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Who is it? Show yourself! No answer. Edith frowns: FLIES are buzzing. The dog start to trot forward, into the dark...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the dog) No. Stay - ! The dog obeys. Looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Brushing away hordes of flies, Edith climbs the stairs an throws open the doors of the elevator - Waiting inside, a decomposing YOUNG WOMAN with a DEAD BAB caught in her long hair... The weeping thing holds out the infant's remains.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Er ist gestorben -! Wahrend Sie wird... Edith screams and lashes out with the iron bar. The figur swirls like oily smoke... and reconfigures, its eyes bulg in supplication. Retreating, Edith tumbles down the stairs. She hits the bottom landing hard - something SNAPS!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She screams, her face contorted in pain. Somewhere, an infant is wailing, a mother is shrieking. Mercifully, Edith loses consciousness. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows glow in the swirling snow. Sharpe's motorcar parked out front, and behind it, a HORSE-DRAWN SLEIGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stolid, bearded young man gazes down on Edith. It's Dr. Alan McMichael! Seeing that her eyes are open...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Edith. Don't try to move just yet, all right? Edith looks around and recognizes the master bedroom. A f crackles in the grate.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Alan - ? Wh- what are you doing here? Is it-

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Easy, easy. You're going to be fine. We need just a bit longer for the plaster to dry. (another smile) Quite a shock seeing me, I warrant. Forgive me. Sharpe and Lucille are watching anxiously from the doorwa

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Edith, we met Dr. McMichael in Blencathra, on his way to us. Heaven- sent, as it turns out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I arrived in Southampton three days ago. I should have sent a wire. (smiles at them all) But I thought you'd enjoy the surprise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: We'd have been at a loss, Edith. Helpless, especially in this weather! It's a miracle, you were bleeding - a compound fracture -! Dr. McMichael is wiping his hands, which are covered in white plaster. Edith's left leg is encased in a hip-to-an cast. Groggy, Edith looks at them, then blurts out...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: The dog ran away. I couldn't find it-

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Shh- not now-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: She spoke to me -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Who spoke to you??

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: She knew my name -

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: It's shock. She'll be quite woolly-headed- (he stops, looks at Edith) What is it, Edith? Are you in pain? Tears are rolling down Edith's cheeks. Her lips are trembling as she remembers... Dr. McMichael brings a cup hot TEA to her mouth. DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) Here. Drink. As she drinks, he places a small BROWN BOTTLE on the nigh stand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's an opium derivative: no more than two drops with hot liquids. Once a day. (to Sharpe & Lucille) No more than two drops, understood?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (lying back) She looked at me - the ghost - and in her arms- oh, God, she was holding something awful. A dead b- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Thomas freezes but Lucille cuts in -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Edith. You were mad to go down there! The mine is ill-lit and crawling with vermin... and you used my keys. And the lift. (to Sharpe) You see? It should be disabled, or locked-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: But I told her - you remember, I warned you, didn't I, Edith?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Clearly, she didn't understand or didn't care-

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (the others fall silent) May I ask... would you take your conversation downstairs? I think she's heard enough for now.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Let me finish here. We must all do our best to see that she gets some rest. Lucille pulls Sharpe by the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: We'll leave you, then, Dr. McMichael. With your patient. They leave. Edith brushes away her tears and tries to sit up.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (falling back) I'm dizzy - everything's upside down...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: It's the narcotic. You may feel some nausea. Have you ever broken a limb before? Edith shakes her head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith smiles He stops her DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) It was a habit of mine, as a boy. My aviation experiments. I fell off the roof twice. I spent my youth in plaster casts. (pause) Now what's all this about a ghost? weakly.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: They don't exist, I know. Until one day, they do. Given enough time in this house, Alan, I swear, even you- with a gentle smile.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, no. A methodical drudge - a pill pusher - is just not cut out for such things. She takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're actually here. Is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I hope so, yes. I'm making certain inquiries. We'll discuss them tomorrow, when you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Tell me now. I can't just lie here - !

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I went to your father's club. Early. At that hour, there are no other swimmers. The floor is perfectly dry. How could he slip? And his injuries... yes, injuries. I saw multiple fractures. Edith is looking at him in horror.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Lie back. You must get some rest. I'm here to confirm a few facts - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What sort of facts? (no answer) I love him, he's more than I ever wished for, he's my life now-

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I know. I wanted to be happy for you. Even as I worried, I've thought of little else. He puts a pillow under her head and touches her cheek. INT. FOYER -— DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) I'm at the Elgin hotel in town. Close your eyes now. I'll come back tomorrow and we'll go over everything.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lucille and Sharpe are waiting as the Doctor comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: She should sleep through the night. Keep an eye out for fever. Lucille hands Dr. McMichael his hat and coat. As they walk

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: We're ever so grateful. Won't you stay here, with us? The roads are awful - we have more than enough room...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, no. I have some business in town. Contact me immediately if there's any change. to the door:

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm only sorry that you have to see her like this. Really, she's taken to life here in the hills. For all her big city upbringing, she says she's never been happier. She's thriving, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I believe you, sir. You're a lucky man.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow is still falling. Dr. McMichael climbs into his sleigh and guides it down t driveway as Lucille and Sharpe stand at the door, watchin They go inside and slowly close the door. Prelap PIANO: one of Liszt's Transcendental Etudes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille's at the piano, working her way through an especially ferocious passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far underground, Sharpe enters the darkened alcove. Heari a WHISPER, he holds his lantern high. An ambiguous SHADOW undulates over the wall, then onto th ceiling -! Startled, Sharpe presses himself into a corner but after a moment, he frowns, seeing that one of the tru is open. As are the photo albums within. He flicks through snapshots of himself embracing the beautiful GERMAN WOMAN with a pudgy BABY in her arms. Mor PHOTOS: the two kissing on a forest path, pushing a baby carriage through the main plaza in Leipzig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe drags the steamer trunk down a tunnel to the edge an open pit. He kicks away a GUARD RAIL, then tips the tr over. It falls... -.-and falls... and falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith opens her eyes as Sharpe enters, pushing the wicker WHEELCHAIR. Lucille follows, carrying a BREAKFAST TRAY. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down her. Lucille 80.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Good morning, my love. Look what we found. It was grandfather's. in the wheelchair and rolls himself over to parks the tray on a bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to play with it. He must have been over six foot tall - far too big for you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: So. Did you sleep well?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I never moved!

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Good: Now try to eat something. Dr. McMichael's orders. She pours a cup of tea and adds FOUR DROPS from the brown bottle. Sharpe counts them with her: TOO MANY. Their eyes meet -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've made porridge, as usual. And a fresh pot of tea. Here. Lucille places the tray in front of Edith, who begins to the cereal.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Tell me. Were there other children living here? Within the last few years?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: No, there were no-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (swiftly) Yes. Yes, one of the housekeepers had a baby. It died. They both died, actually. After leaving the country, more than ten years ago -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Was her name Eleanora Schott?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Precisely. She was a German woman, highly educated. Of course you remember her, Thomas. How Finlay adored her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Their eyes are riveted on the cup of tea. They watch as Edith brings it to her lips - pretending to drink.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I do remember, yes.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Her things are here in the house. I saw a book - but the date was 1897... just three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: She left everything when she returned to Leipzig. But you must have misread the date. Edith replaces the cup on the saucer; the tea is untouche Having another spoonful of porridge... Again, Edith brother.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And Pamela Upton? Margaret McDermott? Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: My piano students. For a moment I thought I might be cut out for teaching. It was a disaster, I'm sorry to say.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: This house is full of memories. So many of them unhappy... We shouldn't talk about them. pretends to sip some tea. Lucille glares at her

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Sharpe) Then let's get out of this room and let your darling invalid enjoy her breakfast in peace. Come. As she propels her brother toward the door, Edith pours t cup of tea into a flower vase next to the bed. Not a moment too soon - Sharpe stops and lingers in the doorway. As he turns back...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thomas. I - I feel such a fool. Snooping in the basement, dredging up sorry things. I will not ruin everything! I promise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: No, it's not you. This place never recovered. When father died - in the library - he - died alone and distraught. He killed himself, Edith. And this house died with him.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: My God- I'm so sorry! What happened? Sharpe returns to her and sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: After mother's death. He went to pieces. Edith reaches for him. He embraces her, visibly moved. Edith shakes

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Edith. Was it a mistake? Bringing you here - to this cold and lonely place? her head. He kisses her gently.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was. If you're seeing ghosts, it's because of me. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (studying his face) No, no. Once, I would have given anything to live among spirits. To commune with them, to be brave and not run away.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Now... I have you. Send them on their way, Thomas, if you can. It is I who belong here, not them.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: You... you are different. So different.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Different from whom?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Everyone.  83. INT. KITCHEN —- DAY Sharpe places the breakfast things next to the sink. Luci checks the teapot.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: She drank it - look. He holds up the empty cup.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Maybe she did, maybe not. It doesn't matter. I put half the opium in the porridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANAGING EDITOR leads Dr. McMichael through a busy newspaper office. A noisy printing press is at work.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: We don't make our back issues available to just anybody. But seeing as you're a medical man... The rear of the office is jammed with wooden filing cabinets. Several EMPLOYEES are leafing through bound bac issues. MANAGING EDITOR (CONT’D) Anything ever written about that family would be in here. We've found a few things. Dr. McMichael examines a photo that has been set aside: a very young but recognizable THOMAS, sitting on a pony. Standing alongside, holding the reins, is a blonde ADOLESCENT GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (reading the caption) "Lucille Sharpe introduces brave little brother Thomas to the joys of the horse ring."

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: Doctor, if you don't mind, at night I have the strangest numbness in my lower back - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: At night, you say? Tell me all about it.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: It's a tingling sensation, right down to my toes... Something else catches Dr. McMichael's attention. It's a newspaper column entitled RECENT WEDDINGS.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: One moment, please. In the text: a PHOTO of twenty-something Thomas marrying Pamela Upton, a fair-haired young society girl from Londo who wears dark glasses and carries a long, white cane. DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) The Baronet. Sir Thomas - he's had how many wives?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: Haven't the foggiest. I've never met the man. On another page, another photo, more recent, of Thomas marrying Eleanora Schott, a wealthy heiress from Germany.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I daresay, you should go back. August 1872. That's the real shocker. The man leafs through another bound volume, this one olde

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've never heard anyone speak about it. As if everyone in the district were ashamed or paid to keep mum. I suppose the Sharpes were powerful enough back then, but even so - it made the front page.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Dear God.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: Dreadful business, isn't it? No photographs then - but here - (he turns to another page) ...the engravings are clear enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. McMichael is speechless as looks at an unseen page of illustrations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator descends and stops. Edith is on board. She glides ghost-like down inky tunnels deep underground. Her eyes are closed; her hair billows, as if underwater. Gaping HOLES and CRACKS pass below her bare feet - but sh floats over them, her nightgown swirling. Magically, Edith is in a...

dialogues.speaker: PENTAGONAL ROOM
dialogues.text: -..-where flies are buzzing. Four of the five walls featu newly-laid, bricked-in CRYPTS. The fifth crypt is still open, waiting for her. Suddenly, Lucille Sharpe steps out from the darkness. Although her mouth never moves, her low VOICE is audible:

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: None of you will ever leave. You'll dwell here in torment, at my pleasure. Edith's eyes fly open as a shining blade pierces her neck A strangled, wet SHRIEK erupts from her lips -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith wakes up. Weak sunlight filters in from behind the heavy drapes, which have been drawn tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith is bent over the toilet, vomiting. She straightens up and tries to clear her head, pausing a the sink to take a few swallows of water. She stops as she catches sight of her reflection in the mirror. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shock: her face is gaunt, her eyes sunken. She brings a c like hand to her throat, which is stained black. Her tong is black, too -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No - no... She brushes against a naked WRAITH - the walking corpse o young woman whose face is half-hidden behind a curtain of black hair. The awful thing reaches for Edith, but - - both her arms are chopped off at the elbow!

dialogues.speaker: WRAITH
dialogues.text: Soon, I say! Ssssoon - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Edith wakes up. This time for real. She looks arou alone in her room. Trembling, she flings off the bed cove and gets to her feet. She's clumsy, teetering on her plaster cast, dizzy from t ingested drug.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thomas?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muttering, hideous SHAPE is rolling through the shadows the upstairs corridor. It's Edith, in the wheelchair. Weak and disoriented, she stops; her head lolls... a MOAN breaks the silence. Another MOAN... Down the hall, sitting outside Lucille's room, is the dog.

dialogues.speaker: IN LUCILLE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Edith reaches the threshold and pushes the door aside. Sh stands in front of a mirror. A man, behind her, kisses th nape of her neck and embraces her suggestively. She MOANS but... -..sees Edith! The man turns around- Is Thomas!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Gasping, Edith blindly rolls herself toward the stairs. The dog runs ahead, barking like a mad thing. Suddenly, t wheelchair jerks to a stop. Sharpe is there, holding her place. She flails at him... he fends her off, his face a picture calm. Then Lucille looms up, stirring a glass of water and bringing it to Edith's lips. Edith hurls herself out of the wheelchair. She hits the floor with a thump, only to be rolled onto her back. Sharpe puts a knee on her chest and pins her arms. He glances at Lucille and nods. Lucille again comes close with the drinking glass. She SL Edith hard, then swiftly grabs her nose and forces the solution down her throat. Gagging, Edith spits the liquid at the woman's face.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Who are you? Who are you, really?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Who do you think?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You're not his sister! Lucille slaps her again and forces more liquid down.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: I am. Edith struggles, reaching for the chair. She tries to cra but Sharpe kneels next to her, holding her down. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: Silence. Then, the boom of the DOOR KNOCKER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow has stopped. Drifts are everywhere. Lucille opens up to find Dr. McMichael on the doorstep, carrying his black bag and a large book - one of the boun volumes from the local paper. His horse and sleigh are in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Miss Sharpe. How's Edith doing?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: She's asleep right now, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: That's fine. Fine. And your brother??

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: He's gone to the post office. He'll be back shortly.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Dr. McMichael, last night... didn't go well. Edith awakened several times, crying out. We were all of us up til dawn.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: If she's in pain, I should see her-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: No, no. She's finally getting her rest. I wonder, do you have more opium? In the dark, we broke the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Of course. (pats his bag) Right in here.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: But come inside. There's no reason for you to freeze to death.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in his overcoat, Dr. McMichael is seated on the sof decanting some liquid opium into another small bottle. Lucille tends to the fire and sits opposite him, eyeing t drug.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well. Back home, everyone's clamoring for some news. Tell me, Miss Sharpe, how's her book been going?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Oh, she talks of nothing else. Quite the imagination, that one.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: A writer's talent is one I've always envied.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You have a taste for fiction, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: I do. Although in my experience, actual events can go far beyond one's wildest imaginings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom is dark. Lying under the covers, barely movin Edith hears the distant voices, as if in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (raising herself up) Alan - ? Across the room, the dog is alert, tail thumping. Edith looks at the open door, then reaches for the rubber ball on the night stand. With supreme effort, she rolls i into the hallway. It almost reaches the stairs when the dog scampers and - brings it back!

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No - no... Fighting off nausea, she again picks up the ball. Throws it... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The dog instantly goes after it. But, in the hall, the animal recoils as one of the hissing spectres - Pamela Upton, the blind girl - springs forth from the shadows! A dry, bony hand guides the rolling ball to the steps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. McMichael is about to give Lucille the bottle of opiu but almost teasing, he pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: You know, Miss Sharpe, I really should examine the patient before doling this out.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (thin smile) And her doctor's orders, what of them? As I recall, he was quite insistent on rest and sedation. A moment of silence as they size each other up. Suddenly, the RUBBER BALL bounces down the stairs and int the room. The dog follows, barking happily.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Ah. Someone's awake. He pockets the opium vial and exits. INT. BEDROOM —- DAY Dr. McMichael strides into the bedroom and draws back the curtain, revealing Crimson Peak. He sits at Edith's bedsi

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: There. Now - if you'll just look at me. Edith gazes into Dr. McMichael's eyes; he checks her pupi then takes her pulse.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Help- help me- take me away... Dr. McMichael picks up the brown bottle, checks the liqui

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. But not now. You're in no shape- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Now! You must -! You don't understand-! I can walk!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: The wheelchair, then- Lucille appears in the doorway. Dr. McMichael changes his demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (to Lucille) She's showing signs of anemia and exhaustion. I'm going to take her to a hospital -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Miss Sharpe, under the circumstances -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Doctor, we appreciate everything... you coming here so fortuitously, doing what you can. But we have decided to seek the assistance of a bone specialist.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: You didn't mention anything before -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: I didn't want to trouble you - or appear unkind. An osteopath is coming from London. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Is he, now?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: In fact, my brother has gone to fetch him at the station.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Then you won't mind if I stay and make his acquaintance. A NOISE from outside signals the arrival of a motorcar. Lucille hurries away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. McMichael immediately takes Edith by the arm. DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) All right. Show me you can stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille opens the front door. Sharpe is already out of hi car, alarmed at the sight of Dr. McMichael's sleigh.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: (seeing Lucille) How long has he been here?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Half an hour. He won't leave.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'll deal with him. Sharpe hands a large postal ENVELOPE to Lucille as he hea for the grand staircase.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. From her solicitor. And the Boston bank. Lucille pulls a thick wad of papers and contracts out fro the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe enters the bedroom and finds Edith seated in the wheelchair. Dr. McMichael stands behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Sir Thomas. We were just going.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Leave her be. Lucille comes alongside her brother. She's holding someth in the folds of her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do you know the Brathwaite Daily Ledger? "The newspaper of record for northern Cumberland." I've borrowed some back issues. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He kneels next to the wheelchair, so Edith can see. He op the book of old newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Edith) Edith. It seems that your mother-in-law, Lady Edwina Sharpe, was murdered, here in this house. Edith stares at him in puzzlement. Then she looks at the open book. Headline: "AXE MURDER AT SHARPETON." CAMERA lingers on a detailed STEEL ENGRAVING depicting a butchered woman in t library downstairs. DR. MCMICHAEL (CONT’D) No suspect was ever arrested.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Did you understand what I said? Leave.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: (turning) You, Sir Thomas, were only thirteen at the time. After questioning by the police, you were sent off to boarding school in Surrey. (to Lucille) Your story, Lucille, is less clear. A convent education in Switzerland, it said.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Sharpe) What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: An entire paragraph describes the condition of the body as it was found. A grisly thing, a hatchet or something similar. Thirty blows -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Enough- BAMM!!! She darts forward and stabs Dr. McMichael in the NECK with a boning knife. Edith screams!!! The Doctor arches back, the knife jutting from under his ear. He staggers out the door, struggling to remove it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith is on her feet, reeling, trying to catch up. SOCK! Lucille smacks her back into the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeding profusely, the Doctor gropes his way down the ic covered front stairway. He finally pulls out the knife, t slips and falls. The knife bounces off the stone steps. Rolling over, he sees Lucille coming- calmly picking up t knife. Then Sharpe is there, followed by the excited DOG. The Doctor scrambles backwards, clutching his wound. He points at Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Who is she, Sharpe? Where did you find her -? Lucille hands the knife to Sharpe.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Sharpe) You do this!! Get your hands dirty for a change!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: Edith... will not die here. Not her. Numb, Sharpe stares at the knife in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (to Sharpe) I'll deal with him, you said -! You've never done anything for us - look at you!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MCMICHAEL
dialogues.text: She's stronger than both of you. Lucille pushes Sharpe forward.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Do it!!! Sharpe closes in on the wounded man and stabs him in the gut.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sorry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He twists the KNIFE, digging deeper. The Doctor twitches, groans and goes still. The dog, tail wagging, licks at the fresh blood on the snow. Repulsed, Sharpe turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille and Thomas drag Dr. McMichael into the elevator. Lucille goes through the man's pockets and retrieves the opium. Then she steps out, and Thomas takes the elevator down un the house. Once he's gone, Lucille brings out the knife a turns toward the dog.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Come here, doggie. Come along, see what I have. INT. CRYPT —- DAY CAMERA follows a BLOODY SMEAR along the floor of the mine tunnel to the brick crypt, where Sharpe is stuffing Dr. McMichael into a dark corner. He tosses the Doctor's black bag and the bound book of newspapers onto the body and leaves. For several seconds, all is still. Then, very slowly, the Doctor's eyes open. He coughs and a surge of blood rolls over his chin. INT. BEDROOM —- DAY Lucille appears at the bedroom door; in her bloody hands, COIL OF ROPE. She tosses the rubber ball at the back of t wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: There. I just put a poor creature out of its misery. It was missing its mistress, a certain German woman. She jerks the wheelchair around: empty. She checks the bathroom - Edith is gone. Lucille throws open one of the windows and looks out fron No horse and sleigh! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thomas! !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHIP cracks... the horse-drawn sleigh yaws into view, skidding down the abandoned main street of Sharpeton. Edith hauls on the reins, stopping at Finlay's hovel.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Finlay!! She gets down from the driver's bench, barely able to sta Gripping a tumble-down fence for support -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Finlay -? Finlay's sheepdog appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith hobbles inside and looks around. The hut's a mess; meagre coal fire is smoking on the grate. Her foot knocks whisky bottle across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Wake up! Come on - She shakes a lump in the bed... it's a pile of old clothe Suddenly, Finlay is standing in the doorway and cradling of the lambs.

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: That sleigh out there... it came up from town.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Yes! That's right! Take me to town, Mr. Finlay!? Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Straightaway, I can. As you say, my Lady - jawohl und schnell! Edith is near to fainting; Finlay grabs her before she blacks out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where's Sir Thomas, then? You need help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith's eyes open; she's back on the sleigh, with Finlay driving now. The horse trots along smoothly... they're making good time. She glances behind - no one's following them.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Finlay - I'm not Eleanora Schott. * Fraulein Eleanora... do you understand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that? She's dead. three years ago...

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: (nodding) I saved a lamb for the baby. She was named Mary, after all.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You saw this baby? They showed you?

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Born in the house, she was. They should have named her Hope. That's what I said, remember? I sat outside, I heard you crying. (looking ahead) Almost there -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (confused) Where?

dialogues.speaker: FINLAY
dialogues.text: Home, my Lady. Whoa -— (he hauls on the reins) Da kommen sie. You'll be all right now. * Sure enough - a CAR HORN from up ahead. It's Sharpe and Lucille, in their motorcar. Coming down f the road to the house, closing in on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorcar is parked in the driveway. Finlay is gone. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sharpe and Lucille drag Edith up the front steps; at the top, she manages to tear free.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (to Lucille) You - you - you're his wife, aren't you!?-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? Because of what you saw?? Two monsters, naked on the bed? Tell her, Thomas. Tell her - Sharpe calmly walks toward her.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Edith. I'm afraid she is my sister. Flailing at him, Edith loses her balance and slides all t way down the steps! She winds up on her back, her broken splayed out. She SCREAMS with fresh pain. INT. BEDROOM —- DAY Edith is tied to the bedposts. Like an animal, she tugs repeatedly at the ropes, finally freeing one arm. Her wri is rubbed raw. She lifts the sheet and looks at her broken leg; a RED ST is seeping into the white plaster cast. As she begins to untie her other arm, Lucille enters and reacts.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Still the clever one, I see. That's fine. Here, take this. She hands Edith a gold-nibbed FOUNTAIN PEN and plops a he of PAPERS before her. Edith recognizes the documents from Boston that will transfer her fortune to the local bank.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No need to read them. Just sign. Seeing Edith's hesitation -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for? You have nothing to live for. He never loved you. Any of you. He loves only me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: It's indisputably true, my dear. The women we found - in London, Edinburgh, Leipzig -

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: - Boston.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Yes, Boston - all had what was necessary: money, foolish dreams and no living relatives. Mercy killings - all of them. Very well, there was love - one-sided, always - we specialized in provoking it.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And your mother? You killed your own mother...

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (mild) She caught us, one day. We were a bit young, I suppose, but it had started and we couldn't stop. I did kill her. To put an end to her screaming. Lucille collects Edith's unfinished MANUSCRIPT from the f of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was sent away. To an institution - She moves to the fireplace and starts throwing the pages into the fire. The burning papers fly up the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was only seventeen years old! The world is inhabited by monsters, uncomprehending and unworthy of pity! Edith's not listening; she's looking at the FOUNTAIN PEN, which she holds in her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Sign your name -! Sign your name!!! Will you sign your bloody name!!! Lucille kneels down on hard on Edith's broken leg. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one hurts me! No one -!! Edith writhes, holding back a scream.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop. I - I can't bear it. Very well. I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Are you? Show me. Edith starts signing the papers.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (inspecting the signatures) Good. It's almost over now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. McMichael is sprawled on the floor, surrounded by the contents of his medical bag. His neck is bound up in bloo cotton; with clumsy fingers, he tears strips from his shi and wraps them around his middle. Hearing something, he pauses. A low MOAN rises up from somewhere - and the house breathes its mournful sigh. Caught in a sourceless breeze, Doctor looks wildly around terrified at what might come next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sharpe fills the tea kettle, a SHADOW slides across th wall. Startled, Sharpe knocks over the coal scuttle - spilling BLOOD across the floor! He leaps away - - but the blood vanishes. Just scattered lumps of coal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith is signing her name on page after page.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: There. Now I want you stay on that bed - it will be just like falling asleep. There's no pain, far from it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Edith gazes at the fountain pen clenched in her fist. Her hand is steady.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What about my father?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Ah, of course - you have a right to know. Lucille can't hold back a small smile of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Such a coarse, condescending man. You should have seen his face when I hit him. STAB!! Edith plunges the pen into Lucille's chest! Lucille lurches, then - WHAM! - cuffs Edith, hard. She te open her dress... Blood pours down her breast and ribs..! She sees a frantic Edith untying her other hand, trying t get to the wheelchair! Snarling, Lucille kicks it away, t exits, slamming and locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, a POT OF TEA is steaming. As Sharpe dumps the entire bottle of opium, his skin begins to crawl. He slowly lifts his eyes. The armless DEAD WOMAN is outsi only inches from the window frame!! Crying out, he grabs a chair and hurls it, shattering the glass..! Lucille bursts in, holding a piece of cloth to her wound.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: What happened? What did she-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (pushing him aside) I- I'm perfectly well! It's you I'm worried about! She inspects the broken window glass, leans outside to ha a quick look around.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She'll take that tea from you, not me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I saw her - ! I saw Margaret - ! Margaret McDermott— (pointing) - just there!

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You'll say anything now, just to keep from going up there and doing what must be done! She slams the signed documents on the kitchen table. A dr of her blood hits the top page, near Edith's signature.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. It's done.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: What we are - what we have become... We must stop.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Why? Why now??

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Because... because she's innocent.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: They were all innocent!! Ominous silence.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you fallen in love, baby brother?? Is that it?? Have you??

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: No - I don't love her...

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I don't love her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Again-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I don't love her, Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: And -? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: I love - only you. I love-

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Only me.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Only you, Lucille. She kisses him and then hands him the tea.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Then kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith has dragged herself to the window. Grabbing the curtain, she hauls herself upright. Then she pulls up on sash with all her might. It moves an inch; Edith pauses, staring out at - - Crimson Peak. Redder than ever. She tries again. The window moves some more. CLACK-! The doorknob turns... Sharpe enters bearing a tra with the teapot, cup and saucer. Edith turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You'll tell me now: was it the money? Only that? Sharpe busies himself with pouring the tea.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: All of those women were alone. They had no one, no prospects. One was blind. They were sad, really... ignorant, without talent... Killing them was almost an act of mercy- He passes her the teacup.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And the child? Your child?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: The child was unwell. Its death was like that of the others. An act of mercy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No. Not mercy. Greed. You killed for money. One after the other, you met and married them... and then... my turn came. Is that it, Thomas? No answer. She throws the poisoned tea in his face.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why? Why must we all die? For your land, your property -? For your name?? He turns away, wiping at his eyes -

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: No - there's no time. I - I can't-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Tell me! For... her? Again, Sharpe can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were only a boy... how old -? Were you so alone..?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Night is never lonelier, never darker than when you're a child-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Why her-?

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: There is no answer! That's the madness of it - the power of it. Even now. Lucille is me- and I am her. That dark thing - she lives inside me. All our lives we felt it - something stronger than love or hate. She is my fate - she made me and she will destroy me.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But not me. She puts on her glasses and takes a few faltering steps. catches hold of her arm, but she tears free.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can walk -! She throws a coat over her shoulders. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For all your words, the truth is plain enough. You're free of her and she's helpless without you. (pause) Now. You're going to help me. Down those stairs, out the front door - then into town. They look at each other for a long moment. Edith has no i what he'll do. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: We only need to reach the motorcar. Stay close to me no matter what. He cracks open the bedroom door. Looks around... all quie As they start forward-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait! You signed the papers - !?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: There's no time-

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: No! I know her. You must get them back-! Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharpe walks into the deserted kitchen. The bank papers a still on the table. But Lucille steps out from behind a cupboard, holding the boning knife. Her face is contorted with grief.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: I thought so. I could see it in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: She will live.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: What have you told her -? What did you promise her??? A country bungalow?? A rose garden?? Sweet children??

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: You're not to touch her, or even get near her. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Lucille eyes him) Is that clear? Answer me!

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: And me?? What happens to me in your happy dreams?? What happens to this house?? To Crimson Peak and the mine?? Or the bodies down there?? Our blood- my fingers, my lips and flesh. Will you forget all that?? She lowers the knife, blinking back tears. Sharpe picks u the papers and reaches out for the knife.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: We knew this day had to come. And now it's happened. It's over, Lucy. She will live. But then, with a MOAN, the house "breathes" again and Lucille - - stabs Sharpe in the chest. He tries to grab the knife f her, but she slashes at his hands and arms. As they struggle-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith leans out into the corridor. She hobbles to the railing and looks down past the grand staircase into the foyer below. The distant CRASH of glassware. A GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Edith goes to the elevator and stares at the call button. She reaches for it... but - CLUNK - ! The motor starts... the cab comes up. Edith can see a figure through the elevator's glass panel

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (backing away) Thomas -? The lift stops; the doors open and Sharpe is there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His shirt is soaked in blood. More blood is pooling at hi feet. She grabs him before he collapses.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thomas- He hands her the bank papers.

dialogues.speaker: SHARPE
dialogues.text: Let's go- now- Edith- A NOISE from below: Lucille is marching up the stairs, holding the knife. Edith squeezes into the elevator next to Sharpe. She quie closes the door and puts her hands on the bloodied contro handle. Then she waits and waits... +..-until Lucille reaches the upstairs landing. Their eye meet -and Edith jerks the handle to the down position! A long, maddening PAUSE - and with a lurch, the elevator goes down! SCREAMING, Lucille rushes forward..! Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fearing the worst, Edith watches the ground floor getting closer and closer. She reaches past Sharpe and centers th control lever. The lift comes to a perfect stop. She turns to Sharpe, bu he's slumped over now. When she pushes open the doors, he tumbles out onto his back, dead. Edith limps through the gloomy foyer to the -

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: - which is LOCKED!

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?  108.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: In no hurry, the knife at her side, Lucille stops and loo at the iron rack near the hearth. Among the fireplace too the SHOVEL is missing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (calling out) Edith - You wish to hurt me, is that it? Very well - Very carefully, she enters the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - but I warn you, in this sort of business, I'm far more- THUNK!!! - the shovel swings out from the darkness and smacks Lucille in the face, slamming her against the fron door.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Hobbling, Edith makes it back to the elevator. Lucille is right behind her. Edith gets in and jams the lever to "down." Descending, she catches a glimpse of Lucille's flayed-ope face, contorted in hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille runs downstairs as fast as she can, trying to kee up with the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lift stops one floor below. Edith sees Lucille coming She pushes the lever again: DOWN. BAMMM!!! The elevator doors shudder as Lucille pounds the Edith watches in horror as the woman cracks open the door and pins Edith's face against the mirrored back wall. The flailing knife cuts Edith's blouse and arms, but ina second she's descending again. There's just enough time f Lucille to snatch off Edith's GLASSES. Slashed, trapped, Edith goes down... down...  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucille crushes the eyeglasses under her shoe. Then she hurries on!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if possessed, the elevator STOPS at the first mine lev Edith furiously works the DOWN lever just as Lucille agai reaches the doors and tries to pry them open!!! This time Edith jabs with the shovel to break the grip of the clawing hands!! Suddenly, the elevator drops like a stone!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith SHRIEKS as the cab hurtles past dim, rocky walls... ..-and jerks to a hard stop, four feet short of the botto SMASH! Edith's head cracks one of the glass panels! As bl streams down her face, she tries the control handle, to n effect. Acting quickly, she forces open the doors, drops the shov and squeezes out the small opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith gropes her way down the stairs and turns on the ceiling lights. Behind her, the empty cab goes back up!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Edith enters the pentagonal room. Looks at th crypts, her eyes beseeching...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (whisper) Help me! I understand now. I know who you are..! Her voice echoes off the walls... she hears only the dist elevator cables humming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's fresh BLOOD on one of the ledges. And on the floo an open medical bag. But no other sign of Dr. McMichael.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Bleeding heavily, Lucille steps from the arriving lift. T knife glints as she comes down the wooden steps. Up ahead, a woman's skirts disappear around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: There's nowhere to run, Edith.

dialogues.speaker: MINE TUNNELS
dialogues.text: Under the pulsating lights, Lucille confidently stalks he prey through a maze of passageways.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: (weird smile) Yes, that's the way! Do you see it yet? She rounds another corner... her victim is closer now.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The end of our labors, a bottomless place where this family came to nothing. Suddenly, the figure ahead stops short, unable to proceed

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. You've found it.

dialogues.speaker: PIT
dialogues.text: The rough-edged PIT yawns before them; Lucille closes in her victim, who stands at the brink, with nowhere to go.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You killed him, Edith. And he loved you. Down comes the knife - only to slice into diaphanous, boneless flesh. Smoke wafts from the wounds. The figure turns- a dead baby caught in its hair!!! It's the ghost of the German woman, smiling from ear to e Lucille SCREAMS, suddenly seeing the other dead women arrayed before her, their spectral bodies rigid, their mouths agape. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lucille instinctively lashes out with the knife -

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're dead... you're dead -! - slashing at nothing. Wheezing, exhausted, Lucille realizes that Edith stands among them, calm and unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me pass!

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You've made them suffer enough.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: They are nothing! Nothing! Let me pass, I say! Edith comes forward, eye to eye with Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: With you gone, they will be free, all of them. Hissing, Lucille raises the knife- Suddenly, Edith's father is there, a plume of blood risin from his head into the air like smoke. Then the shovel clangs against LUCILLE's head!!! Wielded -Edith. The blow sends Lucille stumbling backwards!! Her feet fly as she disappears over the edge of the pit. A final WAIL as she's swallowed up in the darkness. The flickering ghost of Carter Cushing turns toward his daughter. His sad smile is full of love.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Father -!?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER'S GHOST
dialogues.text: Leave... live. Edith's face is suddenly lit by shimmering warm light... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (half-blinded) Wait - Father, wait..! But its too late, he's gone. Gradually, the light fades a the diaphanous women recede into the walls. Edith looks down: she's holding the shovel. Edith realizes that Dr. McMichael is leaned up against th rock wall, wrapped in bloody bandages; his face is rigid shock at what he has witnessed. As their eyes meet... She rushes to him and catches him before he collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith limps down a mine tunnel, supporting the barely conscious Doctor. A gust of cold air brushes her cheek. The tunnel slopes upward, toward a glow of daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sharpe mansion is a half mile away. Old sheds and rusted mining equipment poke up from the sn drifts. In the middle of the debris, a tumbled-down MINE ENTRANCE. Edith comes out and approaches CAMERA. Her face is smudge bloodied, but set in determination. She clings to the Doctor, urging him on.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As I left the nightmare behind me, I knew that peace had come to the loving souls who sought only to help me. And damnation would be the fate of the real monsters of * Crimson Peak. * She raises her eyes to the mountain, glowing red under * lowering skies.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was here that I found myself empty yet * content with the universe. It was here- * in the cold indifference of winter, on the edge of death, that I decided to live once and for all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SNOW begins to fall in big, wet flakes as they make their way toward the road... -..-and CAMERA PULLS away, higher and higher. DISSOLVE TO WHITE.
